Maintaining this strong relationship requires sustained effort from both sides. India should address potential disagreements proactively and work towards deepening the partnership in various domains.

item.title: MUDRA 2.0 loans should target greater equity, deepen financial literacy
item.description:
The Pradhan Mantri MUDRA Yojana (PMMY) has been a significant initiative for empowering small and micro businesses in India. The scheme has disbursed over 27.75 lakh crore to 47 crore entrepreneurs, with a high proportion going to women and marginalized groups, promoting financial inclusion and economic growth. While successful, PMMY faces challenges such as uneven regional distribution of loans, inadequate monitoring, and financial literacy gaps among beneficiaries. This has led to higher NPAs in certain categories and hindered the scheme's full potential.
Moving forward, MUDRA 2.0 needs to focus on strengthening outreach in rural areas, enhancing financial literacy programs, implementing a robust credit guarantee mechanism, and improving monitoring and evaluation systems. These measures will help ensure that the benefits of the scheme reach the intended beneficiaries and contribute to sustainable economic development.

item.title: Many questions about ‘one nation, one election’
item.description: A high-level committee, headed by former President Ram Nath Kovind, has recommended simultaneous elections for the Lok Sabha and state assemblies in India. The committee, formed to suggest concrete implementation measures for simultaneous elections, analyzed public opinion, expert insights, and legal provisions. While 80% of the 21,558 responses received favored the concept, opposing parties raised concerns about marginalization of regional players and a potential shift towards a presidential form of governance. The report proposed amendments to the Constitution, including a new article "simultaneous elections" would mean general elections for the Lok Sabha and all Vidhan Sabhas together, excluding Panchayat elections which would be held within 100 days. The committee emphasized the need for a single electoral roll and acknowledged the logistical challenges and increased expenditure required for simultaneous polls.

item.title: Vandita Mishra writes | In America and in India: The neighbour test
item.description:
The article discusses the challenges faced by Kamala Harris in her bid for US presidency, highlighting the need for political leaders to bridge divides and connect with those who hold opposing views.
Drawing parallels with the political climate in India, the article emphasizes the importance of empathy and understanding in fostering a sense of community. It criticizes both US and Indian political leaders for stoking division and failing to bridge the gap between supporters and opponents. The author urges leaders to prioritize respectful dialogue and engagement with those who hold different perspectives, calling it a crucial test for any democracy.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder: When a chief minister’s protest becomes a symbol of state abdication
item.description:
The rape and murder of a postgraduate trainee doctor in Kolkata has sparked widespread protests and ignited a national debate on safety and security, particularly for women.
The incident has drawn parallels to the 2012 Delhi rape case, highlighting a disturbing trend of violence against women. Political leaders, from differing parties, have expressed concern and called for stronger action against perpetrators.
A historical figure, Dr Radha Gobinda Kar, whose hospital the victim worked at, is also being invoked in this context, as his dedication to healthcare resonates with the protesters' demand for a better and safer Bengal. Public anger over the crime stems from a perceived breakdown in law and order and a sense that the state has failed to protect its citizens. The protests reflect a collective yearning for change, better governance, and a society where women can live without fear.

item.title: Truth about women’s abuse in Malayalam cinema is out. Does anyone really care?
item.description:
The Hema Committee report, examining workplace issues for women in the Malayalam film industry, exposed serious sexual harassment and widespread exploitation. However, the response to the report has been marred by apathy, sensationalism, and a focus on individual experiences rather than systemic issues.
There is a tendency to deflect responsibility and cast doubt on the validity of women's experiences, while simultaneously suggesting they should pursue legal action despite the challenges involved. The report's damning findings highlight the need for concrete action, not mere lip service. The Kerala government, lauded for its initial steps towards gender inclusion, now faces a critical juncture: will it succumb to apathy or demonstrate the political will to implement meaningful change?

item.title: The myth of the A-team
item.description: Reed Hastings, co-founder of Netflix, advocates for a highly competitive work environment based on his "Keeper Test," where employees are constantly evaluated and those deemed unworthy are swiftly let go. This approach, while fostering freedom for high performers, creates a climate of fear and anxiety. The system is compared to a sports team with players constantly vying for their position, and critics argue it reflects a primal "survival of the fittest" mentality within the modern workplace. Hastings' ideology, while successful for Netflix, raises concerns about the long-term impact on employee well-being and the sustainability of a workplace built on constant pressure and elimination.

item.title: 50 years ago, a nurse was attacked in a Mumbai hospital. What changed, what didn’t
item.description:
In 1973, nurse Aruna Shanbaug was sexually assaulted and left in a vegetative state by a colleague at King Edward Memorial Hospital in Mumbai. The attacker, a contract sweeper, was convicted of attempted murder and robbery, but not sexual assault.
Aruna lived in a hospital ward for 42 years until her death in 2015. Her case highlighted the vulnerability of women health workers and sparked discussion about passive euthanasia.
Despite Aruna's case and other incidents of violence against women in healthcare settings, concerns surrounding safety and security for women in healthcare remain largely unaddressed.

item.title: Inside Track by Coomi Kapoor: Family Friction
item.description: A recent rape and murder at a medical college in Kolkata has exposed a rift between West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee and her nephew, Abhishek Banerjee. While Abhishek demands harsh punishment for the accused, Mamata faced criticism for her handling of the case, including alleged attempts to protect a tainted former principal. Tensions within the ruling Trinamool Congress party have heightened following the incident. In unrelated news, the ousting of former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina from power has led to India hosting her in a state of limbo. Seeking asylum, Hasina is currently stuck in India as the UK has delayed its response to her request. This situation has sparked concerns about the potential for political instability in the region, especially in West Bengal.

item.title: Tavleen Singh writes: Rape as a political weapon
item.description: The article criticizes the Indian political establishment for its inadequate response to the rampant issue of rape in the country. It argues that politicians' insistence on not "politicizing" these crimes reveals their lack of empathy and genuine commitment to addressing the root causes of sexual violence. The author highlights instances where certain rapes garner political attention while others are ignored, depending on their sensitivity to ruling parties. The article further condemns the freeing of convicts in the Bilkis Bano case and the RSS chief's dismissive remarks regarding the prevalence of rape in India. It emphasizes the need for the media to shed light on every case and calls upon political leaders to prioritize justice and safety for women by enforcing existing laws and preventing further victimization.

item.title: P Chidambaram writes: Vision or division
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 11th consecutive Independence Day speech, his longest yet, focused on India's progress but also drew criticism for targeting a segment of the population. Modi labeled those who oppose the nation's development as having a "perverse mindset," raising concerns about his tone vis-a-vis democratic dissent.
The speech also reiterated support for the Uniform Civil Code (UCC) and One Nation, One Election (ONOE), sparking debate. The PM characterized existing personal law codes as "communal," a statement seen by some as biased and lacking understanding of the nuances involved. He called for a "secular civil code," a goal that requires extensive consultations and careful consideration.
Modi's speech remained divisive, continuing with rhetoric targeting the Congress party and raising concerns about potential further division through policies like the UCC and ONOE. The speech's inflammatory language fueled fears that the government might push through legislation that could exacerbate societal rifts.

item.title: In Bangladesh press, a question: Should students be allowed to protest?
item.description:
A survey by Prothom Alo revealed strong public support for ending student politics in Bangladesh, attributed to frustration with the current system. While some outlets see this sentiment as a sign of disillusionment, others view the student protests as a positive force for change, demonstrating youth activism and a renewed sense of hope for democracy.
Recent floods in eastern Bangladesh, affecting hundreds of thousands and causing casualties, have sparked debate about India’s role. While India denies opening its Dumbur dam, contributing to the flooding, some Bangladeshi publications see it as a factor. The focus, however, remains on relief efforts and helping those affected by the disaster.

item.title: After PM Modi’s historic visit to Ukraine, a question: Do Kyiv, the West really want India to play a role in mediating with Russia?
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's visit to Ukraine reflects India's intricate balancing act between its desire for peace and its strategic ties with Russia. While affirming its commitment to international law and a peaceful resolution, India appears hesitant to adopt measures that would significantly antagonize Russia, such as halting oil imports.
This approach echoes India's stance during the Soviet-Afghan War, where the US pushed for India's influence on Russia but ultimately restricted India's role in shaping the post-withdrawal scenario.
The current situation presents a similar dilemma for India as the geopolitical landscape is shaped by competing interests between the US-led West and China-Russia alliance. While PM Modi emphasizes dialogue and innovative solutions, Ukraine's expectations for a more assertive Indian role remain unclear.

item.title: After PM Modi’s historic visit to Ukraine, a question: Do Kyiv, the West really want India to play a role in mediating with Russia?
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Ukraine highlighted India's commitment to peace and diplomacy in the conflict.
While India publicly supports international law and territorial integrity, its pragmatism is evident in its willingness to engage all stakeholders to find practical solutions for peace. India's position is complex, balancing its historical ties with Russia and its desire to uphold global order.
While Western powers and Ukraine may want India to exert more pressure on Russia, there is no indication that they seek a significant Indian intervention. Nonetheless, India's role as a global player is evolving, and its efforts to mediate the conflict could contribute to finding a lasting solution.
The visit marks a step forward in India-Ukraine relations, which have historically been strained, but presents challenges in navigating the geopolitical complexities of the conflict.

item.title: Express View on Modi-Zelenskyy meet: Momentous in Kyiv
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's visit to Kyiv marks a significant shift in India's foreign policy by rebalancing its relations with Russia and Ukraine. India's previous avoidance of high-level engagement with post-Soviet Ukraine and Central European countries has ended, signalling a departure from past deference to Russia. Modi's visit to Kyiv signifies a correction to India's approach regarding the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Notably, India has spoken out against Russia's actions, emphasized its commitment to territorial sovereignty, and expressed empathy for the Ukrainian people.
This rebalancing does not diminish India's relationship with Russia but rather elevates its engagement with Ukraine and Central Europe. India's reorientation is a clear indication that 21st-century realities will guide its European policies, moving away from 20th-century ideological constraints.

item.title: Kolkata rape case: From Pakistan to India, the same misogyny
item.description:
A recent rape and murder of a trainee doctor in Kolkata has sparked outrage and protests in India and Pakistan, highlighting the pervasive issue of violence against women, particularly in the medical field. Female doctors face a lack of safety measures and often experience harassment and intimidation from patients and their attendants.
Similar incidents have occurred in Pakistan, leading to calls for better protection and an end to the misogynistic attitudes that contribute to these crimes. Protests and online campaigns emphasize the need for a societal shift to create safe workplaces for women. While laws exist against sexual assault, the problem persists due to societal norms, lack of reporting, and inadequate enforcement. Addressing the root cause of this violence, the desire for power and control over women, is crucial to ensuring a future where women, including doctors, can work and live without fear.

item.title: Why RBI’s attempts to control the Rupee can have adverse consequences
item.description: The article argues that the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) recent regulatory measures aimed at managing the Indian rupee's volatility are misguided. It contends that currency fluctuations are a natural market response and that using regulations for currency control introduces uncertainty and increases business costs. Three examples are given: prohibiting speculative trading in rupee-linked derivatives, regulating offshore trading platforms, and instructing banks on trading positions. The authors believe these actions damage market liquidity, hinder trading, and undermine the RBI's primary role of ensuring financial system stability. They advocate for a market-driven approach to exchange rate management instead.

item.title: Why J&K assembly elections could end the domination of family-run parties
item.description:
Jammu and Kashmir is set to hold its first assembly elections since becoming a Union Territory in 2019. The elections, spanning three phases, will see major political players including national parties like the BJP and Congress, and regional parties like the NC and PDP vying for power.
The BJP holds a strong presence in the Jammu region, while the NC hopes to regain its influence in the Kashmir Valley. The emergence of a pro-separatist outfit, the Awami Ittehad Party (AIP), led by Engineer Rashid, adds another dimension to the political landscape.
The NC's election manifesto, focusing on the restoration of Article 370 and the release of detainees, has sparked controversy, drawing criticism for its alleged separatist agenda and disregard for Jammu's marginalized communities. The elections are expected to be closely contested, with the outcome potentially shaping the future of the region.

item.title: How not to tax multi-national corporations
item.description: Recent years have seen a push for a more equitable global tax system. After the global financial crisis, the OECD spearheaded an initiative that included 15 action points to address profit-shifting by multinationals. However, disagreements emerged around the allocation of taxing rights for large tech companies. This led to frustration among developing nations and ultimately a call for a UN-led global tax convention. Despite resistance from developed countries like the US and UK, 125 nations, including India, voted in favor of the convention. The UN has now released a draft convention, which aims to address tax avoidance and evasion, particularly by high-net-worth individuals While promoting sovereignty, it also seeks a fair allocation of taxing rights. However, the success of the UN-led initiative hinges on its ability to overcome both logistical challenges, such as duplicate efforts, and political hurdles, including divergent economic interests.

item.title: Time to reset the GST system
item.description: While GST revenues have been robust, many states oppose changing the five existing tax slabs. However, experts argue that when collections are strong, it's the perfect time to rationalize rates. This includes reducing the number of slabs and reviewing the items under each one. The current system is confusing and unfair, with discrepancies in rates for similar products like cement, milk, and edible oils. Simplifying the slabs would promote economic growth and ultimately lead to higher tax revenues. States should also explore non-tax revenue sources like user charges and property registrations to boost the economy.

item.title: Lateral entry scheme puts competence above quota politics
item.description:
The article critiques the withdrawal of India's lateral entry scheme for government positions.
It argues that the scheme, aimed at bringing in external professionals, is necessary to improve governance and address complex development challenges.
The author contends that competence and commitment, rather than caste, should be paramount in public service. They criticize the opposition to lateral entry, particularly from those who prioritize quotas, and highlight the need for a more meritocratic system that benefits all citizens, especially marginalized communities.
The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of building expertise in underrepresented groups and fostering a culture of service above all else within the government.

item.title: What a penguin’s death tells us about love and loss
item.description: Joan Didion's experience with grief, as explored in "The Year of Magical Thinking," highlights its universal nature. Animals too exhibit grief, as seen in the mourning of penguins for their partners and dogs for their owners, demonstrating the depth of emotional connections across species. Helen McDonald's book "H is for Hawk" portrays the transformative power of nature in healing grief, emphasizing resilience and adaptation. While grief undeniably impacts all living beings, the animal kingdom also offers valuable lessons in navigating its complexities and finding strength in the face of loss.

item.title: In Kamala Harris’ speech, an American story — and a missing link
item.description: Kamala Harris became the second woman and first person of Indian origin to be nominated for US president by a major party. Her acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention emphasized unity and her commitment to representing all Americans. Harris's historic candidacy has energized the Democratic party and her campaign aims to appeal to both diverse and working-class voters. While she connected with Democrats with her criticism of Donald Trump, she faces the challenge of resonating with those who continue to support him.

item.title: Application for cancellation of former CM A R Antulay’s bail rejected
item.description: Sri Lankan President Jayewardene announced the government's intention to establish provincial councils across the country as a form of devolution. The ongoing district councils will remain in place but the new provincial councils will supplement them. This decision aligns with Jayewardene's proposal for a second chamber introduced at an all-party conference addressing concerns of Sri Lankan Tamils.

item.title: I adopted my daughter. Recent changes in law could help others get the same happiness
item.description: The author reflects on the challenges of motherhood, drawing a comparison between her experience as an adoptive parent and that of biological mothers. She highlights the unique stressors faced by biological mothers, such as pregnancy complications, labor pain, breastfeeding difficulties, and dietary restrictions due to their baby's colic. Although adoption involves a lengthy wait, the author finds solace in avoiding these specific challenges. She expresses gratitude for her experience and hopes more prospective parents consider adoption.

item.title: My house is a Starbucks
item.description: The article reflects on the profound impact of change on personal memories and identity. The author describes the bittersweet feeling of encountering their childhood home, now a Starbucks, amidst the evolving landscape of Mumbai. Despite the tangible transformation, the author's deep-seated memories of family life, neighbours, and playfulness linger. This juxtaposition highlights the struggle to reconcile cherished past experiences with the realities of a city in constant flux. The author questions the essence of "home," contemplating whether it is a physical space or an intangible feeling that transcends its material form. Ultimately, the article is a poignant exploration of how personal narratives intertwine with the ever-changing fabric of a beloved city.

item.title: Kamala Harris reaches out across the aisle — but points a finger at Trump voter
item.description: Kamala Harris's nomination as the Democratic presidential candidate was met with enthusiasm, seen as a beacon of hope after four years of political turmoil. Her campaign has emphasized her competence and compassion, drawing parallels to a religious fervor. However, her acceptance speech veered towards demonizing former President Donald Trump, employing a "bogeyman" approach that risks alienating potential voters. While the Democrats attempt to frame Harris as a unifier, concerns remain about their ability to address social issues effectively. The election promises to be a closely fought battle, with both parties striving to connect with the anxieties and aspirations of American voters.

item.title: August 23, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Opposition Rally
item.description: Opposition leaders held a rally in Delhi to protest against perceived democratic erosion in Andhra Pradesh. The event was attended by representatives from various parties who condemned the actions of the Congress government in the state. The rally specifically addressed the situation surrounding the claims of support made by Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister Bhaskara Rao to the Governor.

item.title: Express View on Tripura floods: Don’t leave it all to the states
item.description:
Heavy rainfall in Tripura has resulted in widespread flooding, claiming the lives of at least 10 people and displacing over 50,000. Rivers overflowing their banks have caused significant damage, particularly in the southern districts. The state government is focusing on public safety and relief efforts while the central government has pledged support.
The floods highlight the need for improved infrastructure and disaster preparedness. The state's climate action plan, however, lacks concrete measures to address these challenges, leaving vulnerable communities like farmers at risk.

item.title: Express View: Lovebomber baby vs Taylor Swift
item.description: Gagni Porwal's song "Lovebomber baby," a heartfelt expression about a painful romantic experience, has unexpectedly become a viral sensation. What sets Porwal apart from past examples of viral "cringe" content, like Rebecca Black's "Friday," is the lack of malicious glee. Porwal's success might be attributed to the relatability of her story, as heartbreak is a universal experience. Additionally, her song offers a message of hope, demonstrating that even without a polished production or mainstream recognition, it's possible to create impactful art from personal experiences.

item.title: How to ensure dignity for the terminally-ill
item.description: The Supreme Court's recent decision denying permission to remove a feeding tube from a patient in a vegetative state has sparked controversy regarding euthanasia in India. While the court distinguishes between withholding life-prolonging measures in terminal cases and euthanasia, the decision raises ethical questions. Critics argue that prolonging life with no chance of recovery causes suffering for both the patient and their caregivers, and raises concerns about judges making medical decisions. The case highlights the need for legal clarity on end-of-life care in India, involving medical and ethical experts, and promoting open discussions about death and dying.

item.title: Express View on ‘predatory pricing’: Market facts and spectres
item.description: Minister Piyush Goyal raised concerns about predatory pricing practices by e-commerce platforms in India, highlighting the potential impact on small retailers. While investigations have been conducted against platforms like Amazon, Flipkart, Shopee, and Ola, determining predatory pricing can be complex. A report by the Pahle India Foundation suggests that e-commerce, despite rapid growth, accounted for only 7.8% of total retail sales in 2022 and has created jobs and boosted sales for many vendors. The report also found that consumers benefit from increased choice and competitive pricing. The Competition Commission should ensure fair play, transparency, and protection of competition in the growing e-commerce market.

item.title: Sanjaya Baru writes: Bangladesh crisis underlines the necessity of political risk management
item.description:
Indian businesses are increasingly investing overseas, but often lack adequate assessment of political risk. Past incidents, like Tata's abandoned Bangladesh project and Adani's Sri Lanka troubles, highlight vulnerabilities.
While Prime Minister Modi encourages global expansion, Indian firms rely heavily on personal connections and "political protection" rather than comprehensive risk analysis. This dependence on external factors, including government intervention, creates its own political risk.
Despite funding research institutions, Indian think tanks often focus on national security and foreign policy rather than country-specific economic and political risks. The lack of
investment in area studies and local expertise leaves businesses vulnerable to unforeseen political developments.
A stronger emphasis on analyzing domestic politics and policies of target countries is essential for mitigating risks and ensuring successful overseas investment.

item.title: When PM Modi meets President Zelenskyy
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's visit to Ukraine is a delicate move aimed at balancing India's relationships with Russia, China, and the West.
Following a trip to Moscow that disappointed Western allies, Modi's visit to Kyiv seeks to restore India's image as a peaceful and principled player on the world stage. While India will likely call for peace dialogue, it is not expected to act as a mediator in the war.
The visit presents opportunities to rekindle cooperation in areas like defense, technology, and energy. India and Ukraine share historical ties, despite past disagreements, and the war has created new avenues for collaboration. Ukraine needs to rebuild its defense industry, while India seeks to modernize its own arsenal by transitioning away from Soviet-era equipment.
Both countries are leaders in digital innovation, offering potential for cooperation in e-governance. The visit is a chance for India and Ukraine to forge a stronger partnership as they navigate the complexities of the current global landscape.

item.title: When a woman walks alone at night
item.description:
This article discusses the safety and mobility of women in cities, particularly highlighting the experiences of women in Delhi. The author recounts her personal experience as a young woman navigating the city and the changes in her behavior after dark. She then describes the origin of safety audits conducted by women to assess safety concerns in public spaces and the subsequent advocacy work that led to various interventions aimed at improving women's safety.
The article acknowledges the fear and limitations imposed on women due to violence and harassment, but emphasizes their continued determination to claim their right to public space and city life. It uses the recent rape and murder of a doctor in Kolkata as a stark example, demanding justice and systemic changes to ensure all women can live with dignity. The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of a new urban vision that prioritizes the needs and safety of women.

item.title: Centre’s lateral entry policy corrects a historical wrong
item.description:
The article argues that the Congress party's criticism of lateral entries in the bureaucracy is disingenuous and a tactic to deflect from its own past actions.
It points out that the Congress has a history of making ad-hoc lateral appointments, often based on personal connections rather than merit, and that these appointments frequently lacked regard for social justice principles. The article cites examples of Congress-era lateral entries, including those of prominent figures like Manmohan Singh and Nandan Nilekani, contrasting them with the Modi government's emphasis on ensuring lateral entries uphold social justice and historical corrective measures. The writer suggests that the Congress is using the issue of lateral entries to gain political mileage, especially in light of their recent electoral losses.

item.title: ‘Stree 2’: When a headless demon’s saga comes to Bollywood’s rescue
item.description: "Stree 2: Sarkate Ka Aatank," a sequel to the 2018 successful horror-comedy, has exceeded expectations by crossing Rs 400 crore in its first week worldwide. The film capitalizes on audience familiarity with the world of Chanderi, where men are terrorized by a spirit, and delivers on the promise of action, humor, and spooky elements. Released at an advantageous time coinciding with a long weekend, it outperformed several big-budget movies earlier this year. The film highlights the importance of good storytelling and "rooted content" in attracting audiences, reminding the industry that entertaining stories with a unique perspective are what truly resonate. While "Stree 2" leans towards humor and spectacle, it raises the question of whether future installments in the franchise will retain the social commentary and feminist themes present in the first film.

item.title: August 22, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Opposition calls upon people to unite against authoritarianism
item.description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi denied consulting with the Andhra Pradesh Governor, Ram Lal, before his decision to dismiss N T Rama Rao's government. The Governor, however, defended his actions. N T Rama Rao met with President Zail Singh and demanded the Governor's removal, the Bhaskara Rao ministry's dismissal, and his government's reinstatement. Opposition parties denounced the government's actions, while the government announced plans to create a new National Security Guard force to address extremist and terrorist activities.

item.title: Big Tech is keeping us scrolling — and bored
item.description: We are experiencing an ironic "age of content" where an overwhelming abundance of material creates a sense of boredom. Research suggests that this isn't due to the quality of content, but rather our own behavior. The constant ability to switch between options and reject things instantly prevents true engagement and immersion. We become victims of our own choices, influenced by the algorithms that profit from our short attention spans and endless scrolling. This cycle reinforces a culture of instant gratification and undermines the ability to fully appreciate any given piece of content.

item.title: Why the gap between bank credit and deposits is worrying
item.description:
The recent divergence between bank deposit and credit growth, with credit growth exceeding deposit growth, has raised concerns among policymakers. The gap has led to banks relying more on short-term, non-retail deposits, which could lead to liquidity issues. This trend is attributed to competitive investment avenues attracting household funds.
The situation might intensify competition for deposits among banks, potentially driving up funding costs and impacting profitability. It's been observed that banks are exploring innovative deposit schemes to attract funds. Credit offtake has been moderating, suggesting a possible alignment between credit growth and deposit growth. The RBI anticipates this trend to persist, although the duration is uncertain.

item.title: Airtel, Jio, Vodafone hike tariffs: Indians are paying more for less
item.description:
India's large and growing middle class makes it a lucrative target for multinational corporations. Despite claims that Indians are price-sensitive, the success of multiplex chains like PVR demonstrates a willingness to pay more for enhanced entertainment experiences.
However, the recent tariff hike for mobile services by Jio, Airtel, and Vodafone, though still low compared to other nations, raises questions about price sensitivity in the telecom sector. While low prices have fueled market disruption and consumer loyalty, the hike might prompt a reevaluation of the perceived value of service quality.

item.title: With PM Modi’s visit, de-hyphenating Russia, Central Europe ties
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's visit to Kyiv is a significant step for India, aiming to shape its engagement with Central Europe independent of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
India’s long-standing relationship with Russia, particularly from the Cold War era, influences its stance on the ongoing war. However, India is increasingly recognizing the need to pursue its own interests and de-hyphenate its ties with Russia from those with Europe.
Modi's visit is not about "compensating" for a recent trip to Russia but rather about fostering good relations with both countries. While India's role in peace talks is limited, the focus is on strengthening bilateral cooperation and discussing perspectives on resolving the conflict peacefully.

item.title: Why laws on sexual violence continue to be skewed against women
item.description:
A recent rape and murder case in Kolkata highlighted the deep-rooted issue of sexual impunity in India. Despite legislative changes aimed at addressing gender justice, including the renumbering of the penal code and the introduction of the death penalty for rape, crimes against women remain rampant.
These changes have failed to create a culture of deterrence, and the state continues to fall short in providing adequate support and safety for women. Resources are allocated towards male-centric forensics while neglecting basic necessities for survivors, like providing them with items necessary after their clothes are taken for analysis.
The criminalization of protest and the de-funding of women's organizations further exacerbate the problem. The societal response is often fueled by patriarchal bias and exposes the selective and partisan nature of the justice system. The reliance on carceral approaches and the persistence of negative stereotypes surrounding rape perpetuate a cycle of violence and impunity.

item.title: Lateral entry in UPSC will further distance marginalised from centres of power
item.description: The article criticizes the recent UPSC advertisement for lateral entry into government positions, arguing that the lack of reservation provisions perpetuates social inequality and marginalizes Dalits and ST communities. It contends that meritocratic ideals don't address systemic biases that disadvantage these groups, leading to their exclusion from decision-making bodies. The author calls for a more inclusive and equitable approach, urging for a review of the reservation policy and transparent recruitment processes. They emphasize the importance of representation from marginalized communities to ensure diverse perspectives and counter the hegemonic dominance of certain social groups.

item.title: Railway jobs, PM CARES funds, internet shutdowns: The many evasions of Modi government in Parliament
item.description:
Questions asked in Parliament are increasingly being rejected under various pretexts, such as "sensitive nature" or "hypothetical propositions." This trend contradicts the historical practice of allowing a wider range of questions.
The government's unwillingness to disclose information about the cost of the new Parliament building, internet shutdown orders, petroleum imports, and even the delay in conducting Census 2021 raises concerns about transparency.
Furthermore, the quality of answers provided has also declined, often resorting to evasiveness and semantic gymnastics. This decline in parliamentary discourse weakens the ability of MPs to effectively scrutinize the executive branch, ultimately undermining democratic governance.

item.title: Higher education and training are beacons of hope for young Indians. But what safety do they guarantee?
item.description: The article discusses the recent murder of a medical trainee at R G Kar Medical College and Hospital in Calcutta, highlighting the deeply concerning issues of violence and systemic failures within the institution. The author recalls past experiences of the hospital's squalid conditions and the broken sense of community among students. This tragic event is placed within a larger context of anxieties surrounding education and competition for secure positions in India. The author cites instances of drowning deaths in a Delhi coaching center and the NEET question leak fiasco, pointing to the immense pressure and vulnerability of young aspirants for a better future. The article concludes by questioning the very purpose of education and training in a system where even those pursuing noble professions are unsafe, urging readers to consider the grim realities faced by aspiring doctors, engineers, and civil servants in India.

item.title: With Indian cricket in transition, the task for Gautam Gambhir
item.description: Gautam Gambhir's first tour as India's head coach did not go as planned. Despite his impressive record as a captain and coach in the IPL, his team suffered an unexpected ODI series loss to Sri Lanka. Gambhir, known for his intensity and egalitarian approach, faces the challenge of leading a team in a rebuilding phase, nurturing young talent, and managing the expectations of a demanding fan base. His tenure will be judged on his ability to secure overseas victories, with a Test series win in Australia being a particularly crucial benchmark.

item.title: What the government doesn’t get about public administration
item.description:
The Indian government is grappling with perceptions of administrative inadequacy and exploring lateral entry from the private sector to address it. However, the article argues that this approach is misplaced. While lateral entry can be effective for specific, well-defined objectives, it's not a solution for the broader systemic issues within the civil service.
The author contends that the core problem lies in the rigid, bureaucratic nature of the system itself, not the individuals serving within it. They advocate for a fundamental shift in approach, drawing inspiration from models adopted by countries like Australia and New Zealand, while emphasizing the need for political ownership and coordination at both the national and state levels.

item.title: The ugly reality of the Malayalam film industry stands revealed
item.description:
The Justice Hema Committee report, released after four years, exposes the harsh reality of the Malayalam film industry for women. The report details instances of sexual harassment, lack of basic facilities, unfair remuneration, and threats. While it marks a significant step in acknowledging the issues, the report calls for more substantial action.
Recommendations include enacting a law specific to women's concerns in the industry and establishing a dedicated tribunal to address their complaints. However, the report emphasizes the need for a fundamental shift in the industry's culture to effectively combat deeply entrenched sexism and power imbalances. It urges the industry to move beyond progressive content in films and implement real changes to ensure a safe and equitable work environment for all.

item.title: Express View on lateral entry in bureaucracy: No short-cuts
item.description:
The recent cancellation of a lateral entry advertisement for 45 mid-level specialists by the Modi government, following controversies and criticism, highlights a trend of government backtracking on certain initiatives. While lateral entry has been advocated for bringing in fresh ideas and expertise, the government faced pushback concerning its potential to undermine reservation policies, particularly in light of recent electoral concerns.
This incident underscores the need for the government to balance the demands for expertise with the principles of social justice. The Modi government, with its reduced majority, needs to demonstrate a willingness to listen to dissenting voices, both from within its coalition and the opposition, to ensure better decision-making and more responsive policies.

item.title: Kolkata rape and murder: When the law fails women
item.description:
The article argues that while laws regarding rape have been strengthened, the true issue lies in the lax treatment of other crimes against women. Dowry deaths, domestic violence, stalking, and harassment are often under-reported and inadequately punished, leading to a culture where violence against women is tolerated. The author highlights the shockingly low conviction rates in dowry death cases and the lenient bail norms for offenses like domestic violence.
They emphasize the need for a comprehensive review of laws and judicial procedures to reflect the gravity of these crimes. Stronger penalties, a stricter bail regime, and a fast-track justice system are crucial to deterring violence and instilling fear of the law. Until then, women will remain vulnerable and abusers emboldened.

item.title: ‘Productive’ sleeping: Dream a little dream
item.description:
Aldous Huxley's call to "dream pragmatically" is being challenged by modern science, particularly in California, where companies are exploring lucid dreaming for productivity enhancement.
Lucid dreaming, the ability to be aware and control dreams, has a long history and is estimated to be experienced by half the population. While some have sought to harness its creative potential, recent projects aim to turn it into a tool for learning, knowledge acquisition, and even remote control of devices.
This commodification of dreams raises ethical concerns, blurring the line between the mystical and the mundane, and potentially diminishing the inherent inspiration and creativity of the dreaming mind.

item.title: August 21, 1984, Forty Years Ago: NTR Alleges Plot
item.description: N T Rama Rao, the former chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, and his supporters arrived in Delhi to demonstrate their majority. Their attempt to meet the President was delayed by a technical issue. Opposition parties urged the President to remove the Governor and reinstate Rama Rao. Meanwhile, the former Governor faces legal action for alleged illegal activities during his tenure. The situation has created a political dilemma for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who is facing criticism for the crisis and its impact on the Opposition.

item.title: PM Modi’s visit to Ukraine, Poland: India’s Central European foray
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Poland and Ukraine signifies India's growing interest in strengthening its ties with Central Europe.
This trip marks the first visit by an Indian Prime Minister to Poland since 1979 and to Ukraine since its independence. It highlights Delhi's recognition of the region's strategic importance in the current geopolitical landscape, particularly given the ongoing war in Ukraine.
India aims to build long-term partnerships with Poland and Ukraine, viewing its engagement with Central Europe as complementary to its relationship with Russia.
The visits underscore India's broader strategy of elevating its diplomatic engagement with Europe, expanding beyond traditional ties with major European powers to include closer collaboration with Central European nations. This shift is driven by factors such as Poland's economic growth and strategic location, and Ukraine's potential for post-war reconstruction.

item.title: Supreme Court verdict on sub-classification of SCs, STs is blinkered to historical discrimination of Dalits
item.description:
The Supreme Court's recent verdict on sub-categorization within reservation policies, while seemingly addressing the needs of vulnerable groups, may exacerbate social tensions among Dalits. Despite the state's claims of safeguarding marginalized communities, reservation policies have failed to achieve true diversity in institutions. The implementation of these policies is flawed, with reserved posts often remaining vacant.
The Court's focus on economic mobility through reservations overlooks the pervasive social discrimination and violence faced by Dalits. It also fails to acknowledge the shrinking public sector and the dominant role of capitalism, which has largely excluded Dalits, Adivasis, and OBCs from economic development.
A more effective approach would involve diversifying the economy to empower these communities as business leaders, entrepreneurs, and innovators, ensuring they are stakeholders in India's growth.

item.title: Who is behind the violence in Bangladesh? It’s unlikely to be the students
item.description:
The situation in Bangladesh following the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been described as chaotic. The violence that erupted mirrors the events leading to the 1971 Liberation War, targeting members of the Awami League, religious minorities, and secular intellectuals.
While student protests initially sparked the unrest, there is suspicion that Islamist groups, potentially including Jamaat-e-Islami, are orchestrating the violence, receiving support from external actors. The destruction of landmarks associated with the 1971 Liberation War raises concerns about the preservation of Bangladesh's history and principles.
India, worried about the unfolding events and potential threats to its security interests, has withdrawn non-essential staff from Bangladesh and suspended visa operations.
The situation remains uncertain with calls for judicial investigations into the violence and speculation about constitutional changes and a potential new Army Chief.

item.title: After Wayanad, time to empower common people to claim their rightful inheritance
item.description:
Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence found resonance in India's fight against environmental degradation. Landslides fueled by quarrying and construction are devastating communities, prompting calls for action. The Western Ghats Ecology Expert Panel's report, highlighting these issues, faced resistance but also generated public support.
A successful people's movement in Chemban Mudi demonstrates the power of collective action. Advances in technology, particularly smartphones, empower commoners to advocate for their rights. The author proposes several steps for improving environmental sustainability and community well-being in Wayanad and other affected regions. These include localizing quarry management, prioritizing tribal-led homestays over tourist resorts, and establishing labor cooperatives for tea estates. The author also advocates for revisiting Wildlife Protection Act regulations to ensure better protection of human lives and property.

item.title: Secular Civil Code will unify, not divide Indians
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's call for a Secular Civil Code (SCC) during India's Independence Day speech has reignited debate. The SCC aims to unify the nation under a single legal framework for civil matters, ensuring equality for all citizens regardless of religion.
Opponents argue it threatens religious freedom, but proponents emphasize that true secularism lies in equal treatment under the law. They point to discriminatory aspects of existing personal laws, particularly towards women, and cite examples of other democracies with successful SCC implementations.
The SCC is seen as a step towards modernizing India's legal system, simplifying its framework, and reducing the burden on the judiciary. Supporters view it as a constitutional duty and a moral imperative for achieving social justice and fulfilling the vision of equality enshrined in the Indian Constitution.

item.title: To be secure or viksit, India’s leaders must listen to those left behind
item.description:
India faces a multitude of challenges in governing its diverse population. While secularism, intended to ensure equality for all religions, has been met with resistance from some Hindus promoting "Hindutva," a stricter version of Hinduism. This emphasis on Hindu identity creates insecurity, reminiscent of Israel, surrounded by non-Jewish populations.
Furthermore, India grapples with deep-rooted caste divisions, economic disparity, and a growing youth population needing employment. The widening gap between the wealthy and the working class fuels social unrest, as “bread-and-butter economics” supersede GDP growth in public concern.
India's future hinges on addressing these issues, moving beyond divisive rhetoric and prioritizing the needs of its citizens, particularly the working class, to ensure a secure and prosperous future.

item.title: Pratap Bhanu Mehta writes: In Kolkata, after the crime, indignity
item.description:
This article critiques the politicisation of a rape and murder case in Kolkata. It argues that while public outrage and calls for justice are understandable, such cases often become entangled with political agendas, ultimately reducing the victim to a political tool.
The author points to the limitations of protest movements, highlighting their episodic nature, urban focus, and tendency to be overshadowed by complex societal issues. They contend that the absence of tangible reforms in law enforcement and the judiciary prevents these movements from achieving lasting change.
Furthermore, the article criticizes the West Bengal government's handling of the case, accusing them of avoiding responsibility, suppressing dissent, and prioritizing political expediency over the pursuit of justice. Ultimately, the author laments the pervasiveness of political instrumentalization of such sensitive crimes, emphasizing the enduring stain it leaves on society's collective conscience.

item.title: Mohun Bagan and East Bengal’s joint protest: A team effort
item.description:
The article discusses the unusual unity displayed by fans of rival Kolkata football clubs, East Bengal and Mohun Bagan, during a protest against the rape and murder of a young doctor.
The rivalry between the clubs is deeply rooted in the history of Bengal and the divide between communities. However, in this instance, the shared sense of outrage and desire for justice united them.
This act of solidarity highlights the power of collective action, demonstrating that seemingly insurmountable differences can be overcome when a common cause is pursued. The author uses this example to illustrate the universal right to fight for justice, regardless of background or affiliation.

item.title: Kamala Harris, out of Biden’s shadow
item.description:
Kamala Harris has unexpectedly become the Democratic Party's presidential nominee after Biden's withdrawal. Despite facing challenges due to her performance in the 2020 primaries, Harris has gained momentum and is currently tied with or leading Trump in polls. Democrats are hoping she can rally young and minority voters and counter the Republican attacks on their economic policies.
However, the ongoing conflict in Gaza presents a significant challenge for the Harris campaign. Protests against US support for Israel are expected at the Democratic National Convention, and growing dissatisfaction among some Democratic voters could impact the election.

item.title: Yogendra Yadav writes: Where are our political thinkers?
item.description:
This article argues that modern Indian political thought has declined, leading to a stagnation in political vision and action.
The author points to a rich tradition of political thinkers in post-independence India who were deeply engaged in shaping the nation's future. However, this tradition gradually faded away, leaving a void in political discourse. While intellectuals still exist, their work is often disconnected from practical politics.
The result, the author claims, is a diminished capacity for political imagination and a lack of compelling alternatives to the dominant political paradigm. Reclaiming the spirit of Indian political thought is presented as crucial for revitalizing Indian democracy.

item.title: August 20, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Farooq ousted
item.description:
Governor Jagmohan dismissed Farooq Abdullah's ministry in Jammu and Kashmir due to the withdrawal of support by 13 National Conference MLAs. The Governor swore in G M Shah's ministry. The central government faces a dilemma regarding the dismissal of Andhra Pradesh chief minister N T Rama Rao, as he is set to demonstrate his majority before the President amidst deteriorating law and order in the state.
Meanwhile, a bomb hoax led to the diversion of an Airbus flight from Delhi to Bangalore, but no explosives were found.

item.title: Express view on SSLV launch: India’s space
item.description:
India recently successfully launched its Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV), a smaller, more agile rocket designed to carry smaller satellites. This event is significant because it opens up space access to universities, startups and individual innovators, diversifying the space sector beyond traditional players like ISRO and NASA.
SSLV's rapid assembly time and lower cost make it ideal for the growing market of small satellites used in various sectors including weather forecasting, communications, and disaster management. India aims to increase its share in the global space economy, currently at 2%, to 8% by 2033 through initiatives like SSLV and private sector involvement.

item.title: Outrage over reform in capital gains tax is overblown. Here’s why
item.description:
The Union Budget 2024-25 has sparked debate due to changes in capital gains tax, particularly the removal of inflation indexation benefits for property sales. While these changes appear stringent, a comparative analysis reveals that India's capital gains tax regime remains relatively moderate compared to other G20 nations.
The budget simplifies existing provisions by unifying holding periods for short-term and long-term capital gains, increasing the short-term capital gains tax rate, and introducing a flat long-term capital gains tax rate. The removal of indexation aligns with international practices, with few countries currently offering this benefit.
The reforms aim to create a simpler, more equitable tax structure, discouraging speculative trading and promoting long-term investments. The increased exemption limit for lower and middle-income groups aims to make the tax system more progressive. Although there may be short-term challenges, these changes have the potential to foster a more robust and fairer economic environment in the long run.

item.title: Kolkata doctor’s death reminds us, the personal is still political
item.description:
The article examines the public response to the rape and murder of a doctor in Kolkata, highlighting the need for a critical analysis of the discourse surrounding such incidents.
It argues that focusing solely on punishing the perpetrators ignores the systemic factors that enable and protect them. The article criticizes the failure of institutions to provide safety, the media's disregard for victim anonymity, and the government's suppression of dissent.
It emphasizes the importance of questioning societal norms and structures that perpetuate gender-based violence and silence survivors. The writer stresses the need for sustained activism and political engagement to bring about meaningful change.

item.title: Ashok Gulati writes: The path to Viksit Bharat runs through fields
item.description: India's 78th Independence Day calls for reflection on achieved milestones and areas needing improvement to reach the goal of Viksit Bharat by 2047. While India has made strides in food security since independence, China's rapid economic growth presents both opportunities and challenges. China's success in agriculture, driven by reforms and targeted support for farmers, has significantly boosted its per capita income. India can learn from China's approach, particularly in incentivizing production of pulses, which are both nutritious and environmentally friendly. Addressing the challenge of nutritional security remains crucial, with efforts needed to improve the well-being of young children. Further investments in research, irrigation, and value chain development are essential for ensuring sustainable food security in the face of climate change.

item.title: August 19, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Protests For NTR
item.description: An all-party action committee in Andhra Pradesh is planning to demonstrate support for former Chief Minister N.T. Rama Rao and expose the alleged unconstitutional dismissal of his ministry. They aim to have the current government led by N. Bhaskara Rao removed and Rama Rao reinstalled. The death toll from police firing on protests against the dismissal has risen to 17. Speculation arose that a similar situation to Andhra Pradesh might occur in Karnataka, following talks between Kranti Ranga leader S Bangarappa and Congress(I) MPs.

item.title: SC verdict on states taxing mining activities: Unfounded spectre of retrospective taxation
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruled that states have the power to levy royalties on mining activities, overturning a previous 1989 judgment.
The court applied this ruling retrospectively to 2004, the date of a separate ruling that signaled a potential change in policy. While this was done to clarify legal confusion, it has raised concerns about retrospective taxation.
The court clarified that this isn't technically retrospective taxation as it upholds a legal position that was always viable, even if not recognized. States are now empowered to collect royalties from mining companies, leading to financial implications for the industry. This situation highlights the need for stable policy environments and the importance of policymakers ensuring a balanced approach to mineral development within the federal system.

item.title: Express View: In India-Bangladesh ties, stakes are high
item.description:
The recent conversation between Prime Minister Modi and Muhammad Yunus, Bangladesh's chief advisor, highlights the importance of the India-Bangladesh relationship. Both sides expressed willingness to move past past tensions and focus on shared goals like development and stability. While concerns remain in Delhi about the new government's legitimacy, there's a shared understanding of the need for cooperation.
Both countries must be cautious in navigating this delicate period. India should encourage former Prime Minister Hasina to refrain from political activities on Indian soil, while Bangladesh should avoid extradition attempts that could strain relations.
The stability of Bangladesh hinges on its ability to achieve internal reconciliation and address its contested history. India's support for Yunus, the new government's leader, is crucial in mitigating the risk of further instability and violence.

item.title: Japan’s Foreign Minister writes: India and Japan, co-creators of new solutions
item.description: The Japanese Foreign Minister underscores the deep historical ties between Japan and India, dating back to the 6th century introduction of Buddhism. He highlights the significant progress in bilateral relations over the past decade, encompassing defense, security, economics, and people-to-people exchanges. He emphasizes the importance of further strengthening collaboration in areas such as green and digital transformation, as well as women, peace, and security. The Foreign Minister also emphasizes the shared commitment to a "Free and Open Indo-Pacific," noting the valuable partnership between Japan and India in addressing global challenges. He expresses hope that his visit will contribute to a new chapter in the relationship, marked by deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

item.title: Vandita Mishra writes: PM Modi’s I-Day speech, between the lines
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 11th Independence Day speech lacked the groundbreaking pronouncements that characterized his initial addresses.
In contrast to his 2014 speech, which addressed sanitation and female empowerment with a direct and personal touch, this year's address felt more restrained. The absence of a compelling "outreach moment" may reflect a loss of confidence due to recent electoral setbacks and a realization that key promises, like improved sanitation and reduced violence against women, remain largely unfulfilled. The speech focused on broader aspirations, such as a developed India by 2047, and addressed the controversial Uniform Civil Code, albeit cautiously, emphasizing a "secular" approach and the need for public discourse.

item.title: Faizan Mustafa writes: UP’s anti-conversion law will create social disharmony
item.description:
The article discusses the contentious issue of religious conversion in India. It argues that while the right to freedom of religion is enshrined in the Constitution, the issue of conversion remains a source of tension, particularly with the enactment of stricter anti-conversion laws.
The author challenges the effectiveness of these laws and questions whether they truly address the root causes of conversion, which often involve socioeconomic factors. They argue that the laws create an environment of mistrust and can fuel communal conflict.
The article concludes by invoking Mahatma Gandhi's vision of a tolerant and pluralistic India where religions coexist peacefully, urging a move away from legislation that impinges on individual religious freedom.

item.title: R G Kar Hospital incident underline needs for legal protection for safety of healthcare workers
item.description: The recent murder of a resident doctor in Kolkata highlights the urgent need for nationwide legislation to protect healthcare workers in India. Violence against doctors and other healthcare personnel has been increasing, leading to widespread calls for a central law. Although a draft bill was proposed, it was withdrawn due to concerns about similar requests from other professions. Healthcare workers face unique risks due to their constant interaction with the public, often during times of stress and emotional vulnerability. Several states have enacted their own laws, but a lack of uniformity creates loopholes and inconsistencies. Protections are crucial, not just during emergencies like pandemics, but for everyday safety. Healthcare workers are merely seeking the security necessary to perform their duties effectively and serve the public without fear. It is time for lawmakers and the public to recognize their vital role and support legislation that safeguards them.

item.title: Mental health of medical students can no longer be ignored
item.description:
A surge in suicides among medical students has prompted the National Medical Commission to address the alarming mental health crisis in the medical field. Surveys reveal high rates of mental health conditions and suicidal thoughts among students, highlighting the urgent need for policy interventions. While existing policies aim to prioritize mental health, implementation remains a challenge due to limited resources and a lack of clarity on strategies.
India's experience combating HIV-AIDS offers valuable lessons for tackling mental health challenges. Successful implementation of the National Aids Control Programme involved creating evidence-based interventions, engaging diverse stakeholders, addressing systemic issues, and prioritizing community-led approaches.
Emulating these strategies, the government needs to invest in robust mental health infrastructure, implement community-based interventions, and ensure accessible and affordable care for all. Civil society plays a crucial role by providing research and evidence-based models for successful rehabilitation and care.

item.title: A safe space, between home & our clinic
item.description:
The article discusses the safety concerns faced by women doctors, particularly highlighting the recent rape and murder of a female doctor in Kolkata. The author recounts personal experiences of harassment and violence during her time as an intern and resident, emphasizing the prevalence of such incidents. She calls for immediate security measures like official transport, adequate lighting, CCTV coverage, and clear signage against violence.
The article also stresses the need to address the systemic issues contributing to this vulnerability, including implementing the Central Healthcare Protection Act and mandatory training on gender sensitivity. The author concludes by stating that the recent incident is just the tip of the iceberg and that a culture of respect is crucial to ensure the safety and well-being of women doctors.

item.title: Disparity among Dalits needs to be acknowledged
item.description: The Supreme Court's decision to allow sub-classification within Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST) reservations has sparked debate. While there is consensus against applying a "creamy layer" exclusion to SCs and STs, views on sub-classification are divided. Critics argue it will fragment the "pan-Dalit identity" and highlight the limited impact of reservation, urging its effective implementation instead. However, proponents argue that sub-classification is necessary to address the vast socio-economic disparities within SC communities and ensure that the most marginalized benefit from reservation. The demand for sub-classification stems from observations that welfare benefits often concentrate among numerically larger and politically organized SC groups. Numerous commissions across India have recommended sub-categorization based on their findings, recognizing the internal disparities within the SC community.

item.title: Tavleen Singh writes: Why PM Modi’s Independence Day speech this year was uninspiring
item.description:
A writer reflects on Prime Minister Modi's speech from the Red Fort, acknowledging the progress made since economic liberalization began in the 1990s. However, they argue that true reform has been lacking in the past decade. While infrastructure projects have advanced and welfare programs have improved, governance has not effectively addressed issues such as corruption and the quality of education.
The writer criticizes the lack of privatization in the government sector and points to the inefficiency of India's justice system and urban planning as further evidence of stagnation. They contrast Modi's promises of liberalization with the reality of continued socialist policies, lamenting the missed opportunity for deeper systemic change.

item.title: P Chidambaram writes: Things are not what they seem to be
item.description:
The SEBI saga involves allegations of financial impropriety within a business group. The doubters claimed the investments were illegitimate, prompting an investigation by SEBI and a subsequent inquiry by a Committee led by Justice Sapre. The Committee found issues with SEBI's investigation, noting changes in regulations and a lack of transparency concerning the ultimate beneficial owners of foreign investors. Despite this, the Supreme Court upheld SEBI's actions and ordered the completion of its investigation.
The matter resurfaced with allegations against SEBI Chairperson Madhabi Puri Buch, concerning potential conflicts of interest due to past investments by her and her husband in entities under SEBI scrutiny. Buch admits to the investments but claims they were made before her appointment at SEBI and were subsequently disposed of. The core issue revolves around whether Buch disclosed these past connections to SEBI, the government, the Justice Sapre Committee, and the Supreme Court, and whether she recused herself from the investigations.

item.title: From protests and suspensions to Noam Chomsky: The decline of South Asian University
item.description:
The South Asian University, established with ambitious goals of regional integration and academic excellence, has faced a downward spiral culminating in a recent controversy. The university, meant to be free from political interference, has been increasingly controlled by the Indian government, stifling academic freedom and independence.
This control is evident in unjustified student and faculty suspensions, unlawful expulsions, and attempts to suppress protests. The latest incident involved a doctoral research proposal that cited a critical statement made by Noam Chomsky about Prime Minister Modi. The university's overreaction, leading to disciplinary action against a professor, highlights a culture of fear and self-censorship. This situation jeopardizes the university's original vision and erodes trust among SAARC member countries.

item.title: Kolkata rape and murder case: Why it’s not enough to hold protests and candle-light vigils
item.description: A massive protest erupted in the author's hometown following the brutal rape and murder of a doctor. Thousands of women and men took to the streets, demanding justice and safety. The protest, lacking overt political motives, stood in stark contrast to the state's usual political climate. This massive display of public outcry served as a potent reminder to the government, highlighting the urgent need for addressing gender violence and underlying societal issues. The author calls for a deeper introspective look at the root causes of gender inequality and stresses the importance of educating future generations about equality and consent.

item.title: Kolkata doctor’s murder: The unfreedom of being a woman
item.description: The rape and murder of a young doctor in Kolkata highlights the brutal reality of gender-based violence. The crime reveals the enduring power imbalances that make women vulnerable, even within institutions designed to provide safety. The incident exposes the gaps between the ideal of freedom and equality promised by democracy and its lived experience for women. Furthermore, the efforts to conceal the crime and protect the hospital's reputation underscore the complicity of institutions in protecting perpetrators and perpetuating a culture of silence. This case serves as a stark reminder of the urgency to address the systemic issues that contribute to violence against women and ensure that democratic principles are upheld for all citizens.

item.title: 25 years after it was drafted, why India’s nuclear doctrine still remains relevant
item.description:
The draft nuclear doctrine, presented in 1999, outlined India's stance as a nuclear weapons state emphasizing transparent principles of credible minimum deterrence and a retaliation-only policy. These principles, while conceived in a changed strategic environment, remain largely relevant today.
India's stance against first use, supported by growing but carefully calibrated nuclear capabilities, helps maintain stability despite ongoing threats from Pakistan and China. Debates around tactical nuclear weapons and concerns about ambiguity are addressed by the doctrine's emphasis on robust second-strike capability and clear communication of its intentions.
The draft doctrine's core tenets continue to serve as a foundation for India's nuclear posture, providing a beacon of stability amidst evolving global nuclear dynamics.

item.title: Ram Madhav writes: The necessity of a secular UCC
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Independence Day speech emphasized his government's commitment to "Viksit Bharat 2047," highlighting India's economic growth and societal progress. He addressed issues like women's safety and external threats to stability. Modi strongly advocated for a uniform civil code, arguing that existing laws dividing the country along religious lines are discriminatory and outdated.
He drew parallels to Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's vision during the Constitution's drafting, emphasizing the need for a secular civil code applicable to all citizens regardless of their faith.
Modi's call aligns with previous Supreme Court rulings recognizing the urgency of a uniform civil code for a modern, equitable India.

item.title: Hansda Sowvendra Shekhar writes: All that freedom has given us
item.description:
The author, reflecting on India's Independence, acknowledges the freedoms and opportunities enjoyed by their generation, a direct result of the sacrifices made by those who fought for independence.
However, the author also points out a new kind of servitude that exists today, fuelled by a relentless pressure to succeed in a competitive job market. This pressure manifests in an obsession with goals, a constant striving, and anxiety. The author argues that while progress is undeniable, issues like corruption, lack of support systems, and a disregard for ground realities undermine the true meaning of freedom.
Despite these challenges, the author holds onto hope for a better future, driven by gratitude for the freedoms they have and a belief that things will eventually improve.

item.title: Seven decades after Independence, the unfulfilled dreams of India’s women leaders
item.description: Indian women activists, even over a century ago, campaigned for women's empowerment. They recognized the need for financial freedom for women to exercise their agency in a patriarchal society. Early organizations like the Women's Indian Association fought for better working conditions for women, including limitations on night work and maternity benefits. The All-India Women's Conference advocated for women's rights, including the recognition of unpaid household work and financial autonomy for women. While progress has been made, particularly in inheritance laws, many of these demands remain unfulfilled. The article urges continued efforts to achieve economic equality for women through financial security, recognition of unpaid labor, and overcoming persistent social barriers.

item.title: Express View on announcement of J&K polls: Long overdue
item.description:
The upcoming Assembly elections in Jammu and Kashmir, scheduled for September and October, mark a significant step towards restoring democratic processes after years of political stagnation. The elections, held five years after the abrogation of Article 370, are seen as an opportunity to address the democratic deficit and the concerns of the people. While there has been progress in areas like tourism and investment, challenges persist, including cross-border terrorism, economic dependence on the Centre, and concerns over jobs and land.
It is crucial for the government to be responsive to the concerns of the young voters set to participate for the first time and work towards inclusive governance that ensures their voices are heard and their aspirations met.

item.title: Hobbies are more fulfilling than jobs — because they give us permission to fail
item.description: A recent study by Anglia Ruskin University found that engaging in creative activities like arts and crafts can contribute to greater well-being than employment. While jobs can be a source of stress, hobbies offer the freedom to "fail" without consequence. The act of creating, regardless of the skill level, can bring joy and self-expression, benefiting mental health. The study suggests that hobbies provide a valuable outlet for relaxation and stress relief, contributing to overall well-being.

item.title: Express View on the hottest July: Bad weather report
item.description:
The world just experienced its hottest July ever recorded, marking a significant shift in global climate patterns. While the cause is partially attributed to El Nino, the unprecedented temperature rise demands immediate action. Scientists are now focusing on climate modeling, especially microclimate forecasting, to better understand and predict local weather variations.
Increasing the density of meteorological stations and improving information sharing between countries are crucial steps to effectively adapt to these changing conditions. Collaborative efforts, like the UNFCCC's Lima Adaptation Knowledge Initiative, can play a vital role in mitigating the impact of extreme weather events. The urgency to adapt to a changing climate is undeniable, as illustrated by recent events like the Wayanad tragedy and the Pakistan floods of 2022.

item.title: August 17, 1984, Forty Years Ago: NTR Government
item.description:
Andhra Pradesh Governor Ramlal dismissed the Telugu Desam ministry led by N T Rama Rao and appointed N Bhaskara Rao as the new Chief Minister. Rama Rao claimed to still have majority support in the Assembly.
This action triggered strong condemnation from opposition leaders and members of Parliament, who labeled it "politically immoral" and "constitutionally invalid." The Communist Party of India blamed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi for the dismissal, calling it "murder of democracy."

item.title: How Britain’s anti-immigrant riots backstab UK’s flailing economy
item.description:
Recent public outrage following a tragedy in the UK was exploited by far-right groups to scapegoat immigrants and non-white people. While economic woes fueled anger, the far-right blamed immigration for Britain's economic struggles, ignoring the impact of Brexit.
Data shows that immigrants, particularly from outside the EU, filled the labor gaps created by Brexit. They stabilized key sectors and compensated for the loss of EU workers, contributing to the UK's economic recovery. The economic downturn is attributed to factors like reduced investment, inflation, and stagnant wages, issues that the right wing failed to address. Instead, they directed anger towards immigrants, deepening societal divisions.
Experts argue that immigration is crucial for sectors like healthcare and housing, which are already strained. Blaming immigrants diverts attention from the government's mismanagement and further harms the working class.

item.title: Authorities have failed them. Arm women doctors with stun-guns
item.description:
The rape and murder of a trainee doctor in Kolkata has ignited national outrage and demand for justice. The incident, coupled with the victim's lack of safe amenities at the hospital, highlights the vulnerability of women doctors.
This tragic event draws parallels with past cases like the brutal assault on Aruna Shanbaug in Mumbai and the 2012 Delhi gang rape, both of which sparked widespread protests.
