Doctors are demanding a central protection act to safeguard them from violence, while the authorities are facing criticism for inadequate security measures in hospitals. The incident underscores the urgent need to address violence against women, particularly in healthcare settings.

item.title: The limits of censorship: Understanding the withdrawal of draft Broadcasting Bill
item.description:
The Indian government withdrew a second draft of the Broadcasting Bill that would have significantly expanded government control over online content. The initial and subsequent drafts drew criticism for seeking to subject online video creators, including those producing non-news content, to regulations similar to those governing traditional broadcasters.
Concerns were raised that the Bill could be used to suppress dissenting voices and stifle creativity, particularly given the government's track record of utilizing IT regulations to limit free expression.
Critics argue the Bill's intent, despite being labelled as promoting "ease of doing business and living," primarily benefits government-aligned media and curtails the reach of critical content. They also point out the futility of such efforts in the current climate of globalized content production and distribution, where creators can easily transcend geographical boundaries.

item.title: How state governments have undermined right to education
item.description:
The Right to Education (RTE) Act, passed in 2010, promised universal elementary education in India. Despite initial progress, the implementation of the Act has faced numerous challenges. A recent Bombay High Court verdict highlighted the issue of state governments attempting to circumvent the RTE's provision requiring unaided private schools to reserve seats for children from economically weaker sections. Arguments used to justify this include concerns over resource duplication and questioning the "absolute" nature of the RTE, suggesting a lack of commitment to the law by several state governments.
The RTE mandates mixing children from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds, aiming to enhance learning and bridge social divides. This provision has been met with resistance from private schools who prefer separate sections or afternoon classes for economically weaker students. Despite efforts from some teachers to implement RTE's vision, teacher training remains a significant challenge, hindering the Act's true potential. The article concludes by expressing concern over the misuse of the RTE to exclude poor children from private schools through regulations that limit EWS admissions.

item.title: August 16, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Arson in Sri Lanka
item.description: Sri Lankan soldiers were blamed for the destruction of 123 businesses in Mannar town. The government planned to give compensation of up to Rs 50,000 to affected residents. Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed concern over the violence against Tamils in Sri Lanka. The Prime Minister stated that India was closely monitoring the situation and that the ongoing violence was negatively impacting India's neighbourhood.

item.title: Express View on Sreejesh: Jersey No 16
item.description:
P. R. Sreejesh, a pioneering figure in Indian hockey, has retired after a remarkable career spanning 329 international matches. His journey, from a humble farmer's son with no prior hockey experience to becoming a national icon, is a testament to his talent and perseverance.
Sreejesh's exceptional goalkeeping skills, characterized by lightning reflexes and unwavering composure, brought recognition to the often-overlooked position. He excelled in pressure situations, earning the moniker "The Wall" for his impenetrable defense, particularly in shootouts. Preserving Sreejesh's legacy, the Indian hockey federation retired his jersey number 16. His impact extends beyond his playing days, as he now mentors the next generation of hockey players in his role within junior hockey.

item.title: Express View: Rumbles in Rakhine
item.description:
A recent artillery and drone attack in Myanmar's Rakhine province killed nearly 200 civilians, mostly Rohingya. While the Arakan Army, an ethnic Rakhine group, denies responsibility, many observers blame them for the atrocity and other attacks targeting the Rohingya in recent months.
The Arakan Army's growing influence in the region has led to concerns, especially as it shares ties with China and controls parts of the Kaladan Road Project, a vital project for India. The latest violence has further displaced Rohingya refugees, creating challenges for neighboring Bangladesh and prompting India to monitor the situation closely.

item.title: Derek O’Brien writes: In Parliament, Opposition is feeling a new ‘josh’
item.description: Since the 2024 elections, Parliament sessions have witnessed a surge in the morale and activity of opposition parties. Several factors contribute to this heightened engagement, including a robust Leader of the Opposition for the first time in a decade, noteworthy performances by opposition leaders like Rahul Gandhi, Akhilesh Yadav, and Abhishek Banerjee, and a diverse and influential opposition contingent. The presence of Sonia Gandhi in the Rajya Sabha also serves as a unifying force for the INDIA alliance. Despite the government's attempts to manage the house with a relatively new parliamentary team, the opposition has effectively challenged the ruling dispensation, creating a dynamic and lively atmosphere in Parliament.

item.title: Anasuya Sengupta writes on I-Day: Freedom is love
item.description:
The article reflects on the true meaning of Independence Day in India. It questions if mere rituals and celebrations truly capture the essence of freedom, suggesting that it requires continuous self-reflection, understanding, and love for others.
Drawing inspiration from her grandmother's experience witnessing the first Independence Day, the author explores the complexities of Indian society, highlighting the importance of unity and shared purpose. She emphasizes the need to transcend divisions and recognize our interconnectedness, believing that true freedom stems from profound self-knowledge and compassion that extends beyond oneself.

item.title: With worst deposit crunch in 20 years, five banking issues to address
item.description:
A shrinking deposit base in India's banking system is raising concerns due to its potential impact on loan growth and the overall economy.
Banks Traditionally rely heavily on deposits, especially core deposits, for stable funding.
However, with deposit growth slowing, banks face limitations in extending loans, particularly to businesses. This could stifle investment and economic activity.
The trend is driven by factors like competition, technological advancements, and high inflation eroding the attractiveness of bank deposits compared to other investment options.
This situation calls for policy interventions like deepening bond markets and encouraging banks to offer more competitive alternatives to savers.

item.title: More than ‘naan bread’: Our diversity is our inheritance
item.description: This article reflects on the author's evolving understanding of Indian identity through the lens of food. Starting with childhood memories of sweets and snacks on Independence Day, the author's journey as a chef led to a deeper appreciation for Indian cuisine's vast diversity and ingenuity. The author highlights the resourcefulness of street vendors and the country's "nose-to-tail" culinary traditions. The article celebrates the regional variations in Indian cuisine, using the examples of different chilli varieties and Kerala's diverse culinary landscape. Ultimately, the author emphasizes the unifying power of diversity in Indian food and culture.

item.title: Express View on PM Modi’s Independence Day address: Speech — and listening
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's Independence Day speech focused on his vision for a "developed India" by 2047, emphasizing the country's potential and urging citizens, particularly the youth, to seize the opportunities. While reiterating his government's commitment to fulfilling the aspirations of the people, Modi acknowledged the uniqueness of his third term and the need for his coalition government to listen to diverse voices.
The speech featured significant shifts in its approach. Notably, Modi reiterated the Uniform Civil Code (UCC) as a constitutional goal, urging a nationwide debate and framing it as a "secular" civil code. This marked a departure from the BJP's previous stance on the UCC. Furthermore, Modi announced plans to induct 1 lakh young, politically unconnected individuals into politics to bring fresh ideas and inclusivity to governance. These pronouncements signaled a potential evolution in the BJP's political discourse, emphasizing inclusivity and sensitivity.

item.title: PM Modi’s Independence Day Speech: Why Uniform Civil Code and One Nation, One Election matter for India’s future
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Independence Day address from the Red Fort emphasized a self-reliant India. He outlined his government's achievements, particularly in empowering marginalized communities through direct access to welfare schemes and disrupting the politics of caste-based patronage.
Modi highlighted groundbreaking economic reforms, emphasizing India's position as a global economic force. He also pointed to the infrastructural revolution underway and the government's focus on emerging technologies and sustainable development. The speech touched upon critical issues like the Uniform Civil Code and One Nation, One Election, underscoring the need for democratic reforms. Modi concluded by calling for a revival of India's civilisational prowess and envisioning a future where India is a space-faring nation. His vision for India is one of an economically developed, socially just, and globally influential nation.

item.title: PM’s I-Day speech: Viksit Bharat, nationalism and contradictions
item.description:
This article analyzes the political implications of the Prime Minister's Independence Day speech, focusing on his vision of "Viksit Bharat" and its underlying message about national unity. The author argues that the speech frames diversity as a set of contradictions that need to be resolved for economic progress, a strategy reminiscent of colonial-era justifications for rule.
This approach, the author contends, contradicts the spirit of anti-colonial nationalism which celebrated diversity as a source of strength. The author further criticizes the emphasis on "reform" as a solution to national challenges, arguing that it undermines the importance of debate and dissent in shaping a just and inclusive society. Drawing from the example of a 1959 film, the author highlights a more inclusive understanding of national identity that embraces diversity rather than viewing it as a threat. Ultimately, the article calls for a political imagination that recognizes the value of diverse perspectives in building a strong and equitable nation.

item.title: Dear ICC, BCCI, and commentators: Don’t trivialise mental health issues of players
item.description:
This open letter addresses a concerning broadcasting practice in cricket: describing on-field errors as "suicidal" or "committing hara-kiri."
The author argues this trivialises suicide, a serious public health crisis, especially given cricket's history of mental health challenges among players. The letter highlights the tragic loss of several cricketers to suicide and the growing awareness of mental health issues within the sport. It also cites examples of how language can shape public perception of suicide and urges broadcasters to adopt a more sensitive and responsible language policy. The author proposes mandatory training for broadcasters on this issue, drawing parallels with the recent shift towards gender-neutral language in cricket. This change, they argue, would demonstrate cricket's commitment to fairness, courage, and respect for all.

item.title: Skilling India — for the world
item.description:
The article highlights the importance of skill development in India's economic growth, particularly in light of its demographic dividend. The Union Budget 2024 emphasizes this, with significant allocations and initiatives for skill development and entrepreneurship. The focus is on modernizing ITIs, expanding apprenticeship training, and creating a conducive ecosystem for young people.
The Skill India Mission is being reimagined for future developments, with PMKVY being a key program for short-term skill development. The government aims to make India a global skill hub by equipping institutions to meet international demands and integrating skilling with general education. These initiatives are aimed at ensuring that India becomes a global economic leader by 2047.

item.title: August 15, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Controversy over paid seats in medical colleges
item.description: The Telugu Desam government in Andhra Pradesh faced a crisis with the resignation of four ministers, including the Finance Minister, who cited dissatisfaction with the Chief Minister's dictatorial style. President Zail Singh, in his Independence Day address, warned against disruptive forces and stressed the need to eradicate poverty and ignorance. On Sri Lanka, opposition members raised concerns about violence against Tamils, calling for a fresh government statement. The Medical Council of India declared it would not recognize degrees from "capitation colleges" due to ethical concerns and the detriment to medical education standards.

item.title: On broadcast bill, government’s welcome step back
item.description: The draft Broadcasting Services (Regulation) Bill, which aimed to expand government control over online content, has drawn criticism for its potential to stifle freedom of speech. Concerns have been raised regarding provisions that would subject social media accounts and online video creators to government scrutiny, including mandatory registration and content evaluation committees. Critics argue that these measures could hinder creativity and innovation within the online space, contradicting the government's efforts to support the startup ecosystem. The government has acknowledged the concerns and withdrawn the draft Bill, pledging to hold consultations with stakeholders before releasing a revised version.

item.title: Harris’ or Harris’s: In grammar war, hope for democracy
item.description:
Debate is raging among grammar enthusiasts about the correct use of an apostrophe in referring to the names of Democratic candidates, notably Kamala Harris and Tim Walz. The Associated Press Stylebook advocates for just an apostrophe after names ending in "s," while others argue for an additional "s," citing clarity.
The ambiguity stems from the complex evolution of the English language, where different rules apply to singular nouns and proper nouns. Interestingly, Harris's campaign appears to embrace both forms, reflecting the fluidity of language. Ultimately, the 'apostrophe wars' highlight the ongoing evolution of language and its rules.

item.title: A doctor’s murder and a broken system in Bengal
item.description: The brutal rape and murder of a doctor in Kolkata has exposed serious failures in the West Bengal state administration. The Calcutta High Court, citing a lack of progress in the case and public faith in the Kolkata Police, has handed it over to the CBI. The handling of the case, including the delay in informing the family and the questionable appointment of the hospital's principal after his resignation, has raised concerns about a larger malaise in the state. This incident has sparked broader discussions on gender violence and safety, but also on the erosion of law and order and the influence of a shadowy political network. The incident further highlights the growing concerns around impunity and the perceived weakening of institutional structures in West Bengal.

item.title: With freedom in 1947, the birth of the people’s Constitution
item.description:
The Indian Constitution, despite its length, has become a symbol of national unity and a rallying point for citizens. From its inception, the public was deeply involved in shaping the document.
Thousands of groups and individuals, inspired by the promise of a better future, sent their demands and suggestions to the Constituent Assembly. They raised issues like education, employment, disability rights, and even the rights of the disabled. The public's eagerness to participate surprised the Assembly and ultimately led to the open circulation of the draft Constitution for public comment.
This widespread engagement transformed the Constitution from a legal document into a shared vision for India's future. Through their collective struggles, Indians made themselves the protagonists of constitutionalism even before its official enactment, demonstrating that the Constitution was more than just a set of rules; it was a living embodiment of their aspirations for freedom, equality, and justice.

item.title: Dear Editor, I disagree: Caste is a system, not a classification
item.description:
The article discusses the Supreme Court's recent verdict on sub-classification within Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes categories for reservation benefits. The author argues that while the verdict is welcome, it's crucial to understand the broader context of social justice for these communities.
They emphasize that systemic issues, such as caste-based violence and lack of social mobility, persist despite India's constitutional framework. The author advocates for a comprehensive caste census to accurately assess the socioeconomic realities of different communities within SCs and STs. They further argue that the under-representation of certain sub-castes within SCs is due to factors like low education and income levels, stemming from historical disadvantages and limited access to political empowerment. The author concludes by highlighting the need to address the root causes of inequality within the caste system and to recognize the diversity within both upper and lower castes.

item.title: India’s aspirants need someone to help them dream
item.description:
The article reflects on the current state of India, highlighting the struggles of "The Aspirant"—individuals striving for success in the face of systemic challenges.
It recounts recent tragic events involving young students and a doctor, emphasizing the need for societal change. The author argues that the key to aspiration is hope and calls for a renewed commitment to protecting and nurturing the dreams of all Indians.
Specifically, the article urges a shift from a focus solely on exams and suggests creating a more level playing field. It emphasizes the responsibility of parents, teachers, and policymakers to provide the necessary safety net for all aspiring individuals.

item.title: Shanta Gokhale writes: On Independence Day, of freedoms and unfreedoms
item.description:
The article reflects on the importance of freedom, particularly for writers and journalists. The author connects the celebration of India's independence with the Constitution's grant of fundamental rights, emphasizing freedom of speech and expression as crucial for writers. Illustrating the threat to this freedom, the author cites examples like the suppression faced by Perumal Murugan and the imprisonment of journalists worldwide.
The author argues that freedom is essential for individual growth and expression, allowing individuals to become their authentic selves. They highlight the importance of fostering freedom from a young age, encouraging critical thinking and questioning authority. The article concludes by stating that freedom encompasses various aspects, including the freedom to dress, eat, and practice one's religion, emphasizing its fundamental role in a just and equitable society.

item.title: On Pakistan’s Independence Day, hope for the future in an Olympic gold
item.description: On Pakistan's 78th Independence Day, newspapers reflect on the nation's progress and shortcomings. Dawn criticizes the ruling elite for failing to uphold the founding fathers' vision of democracy, constitutionalism, and minority protection. The Express Tribune emphasizes both the challenges and achievements, urging a transformative rewrite of Pakistan's narrative. News International highlights inconsistent economic policies as a key factor in the nation's current struggles, recommending a focus on education, healthcare, and technology. Dawn's Rafia Zakaria notes the strain on resources posed by Pakistan's youth bulge, while The Nation points to the divisiveness and social disorders plaguing the country, particularly in Balochistan. Despite these challenges, there's a glimmer of hope, symbolized by athlete Arshad Nadeem's Olympic gold, offering a moment of national pride.

item.title: At coaching centres, education is just another product
item.description:
The coaching industry in India, despite concerns and regulations, continues to prioritize profit over student well-being. This has led to several tragedies and a system that focuses on rote learning and exam pressure rather than holistic development.
The education system needs to shift its focus from cramming information to nurturing individual potential and fostering a love for learning. Schools should play a more central role in preparing students for competitive exams while also providing a well-rounded education that caters to diverse interests and talents.
A system that merges scholastic instruction with exploration and personalized growth is needed. Only then can India move towards a future where education truly empowers individuals to flourish and contribute to society.

item.title: On sub-classification of SC, ST, apex court should clear confusion over creamy layer
item.description:
The Supreme Court's recent caste classification verdict has sparked debate about its effectiveness in promoting equality. While the intention to expand reservation benefits is commendable, the verdict's loopholes may hinder democratic progress.
Critics argue that prioritizing political equality over social and economic equality has marginalized scheduled castes and tribes. The success of affirmative action hinges on addressing economic inequality and dismantling the power structures of Brahmanical hegemony.
Furthermore, the 50% reservation cap and the absence of quotas in the private sector remain major obstacles. The judiciary's inconsistent stance on affirmative action, evident in contrasting rulings across states, further complicates the issue.
Addressing caste-based discrimination requires a multi-pronged approach, including a caste census, scientific data-driven policymaking, and a commitment to "annihilation of caste" by ensuring equal opportunities for all marginalized groups.

item.title: From Arab Spring to Bangladesh regime fall — ‘jobless growth’ is a national security issue
item.description:
Bangladesh experienced an uprising fueled by widespread youth frustration due to jobless growth. Despite a positive GDP growth rate, employment growth remained stagnant, leading to economic disparity and social unrest. This situation, exacerbated by political autocracy, triggered violent protests that ultimately forced the Prime Minister to flee the country.
Jobless growth has become a significant security concern for many low- and middle-income nations, as it contributes to social instability and political violence. The Bangladesh example highlights the urgent need for policymakers to address this issue, focusing on inclusive growth and creating employment opportunities for the youth. Ignoring the issue can lead to dire consequences, as seen in Bangladesh's recent turmoil.

item.title: August 14, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Sri Lankan army troops set fire to a Tamil-dominated town
item.description: Sri Lankan army troops retaliated against a Tamil guerilla ambush by burning down the Tamil-dominated town of Manner. The ambush, which took place in Kaithady, Chunnakam and Kayta, resulted in the deaths of 30 Tamil extremists.

item.title: Trump and Musk are not as entertaining as they think they are
item.description:
Elon Musk and Donald Trump's recent two-hour interview, streamed on X, proved more predictable than entertaining. The conversation was filled with conspiracy theories, self-promotion, and attacks on political and regulatory opponents.
While both men are successful in their respective fields, they struggled to engage in a compelling discussion. Their reliance on familiar tactics like demagoguery and name-calling ultimately made the interview lackluster.

item.title: The post-Mandal moment is here — and it calls for a new politics
item.description:
The Supreme Court's recent ruling allowing states to sub-classify SCs and STs for reservations has sparked both political avoidance and criticism from advocates of the reservation policy. This ruling reflects the complexities and uncertainties surrounding the post-Mandal era.
Mandal, a concept encompassing caste politics, evolved in two phases. The pre-Mandal period witnessed struggles against caste, influenced by figures like Jyotiba Phule and Periyar, culminating in the recognition of backward castes in electoral politics from 1967 onwards.
The post-Mandal phase, marked by the judicial debate and implementation of reservations, saw a shift toward viewing numerical representation as the sole solution to social injustice. This approach, while reinforcing the reservation regime, arguably overshadowed the broader goals of dismantling caste-based hierarchies.
The ruling raises critical questions about the effectiveness and future trajectory of reservation policy.
It necessitates a reassessment of the social blocs on which reservations are based, considering their evolving nature and internal divisions. The challenges of addressing new power asymmetries beyond the confines of caste, class, and power require fresh approaches and political discourse.

item.title: RBI employment data should be read with a caveat
item.description:
The KLEMS data, often cited to support claims of robust job creation in India, relies on projected population figures and worker-population ratios (WPR) derived from employment surveys. The methodology has limitations, including potential overestimation of labor force due to high projected population growth, especially in rural areas, and the inclusion of subsidiary employment, often involving unpaid family workers.
Concerns arise about the temporal comparability of WPR data shifting from the Employment-Unemployment Surveys (EUS) to the Periodic Labour Force Surveys (PLFS), and the use of projected population figures from the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, which may be inflated. Comparisons with data from the Annual Survey of Unincorporated Sector Enterprises (ASUSE) further cast doubt on the accuracy of employment figures. Given these methodological issues, claims of significant job creation based solely on KLEMS data warrant critical examination.

item.title: Express View on Muhammad Yunus government: Keep the social peace
item.description:
Following the ouster of Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh now faces a period of uncertainty. Muhammad Yunus, the Nobel Laureate economist, has been tasked with leading the interim government. His primary challenge lies in uniting the deeply divided country and restoring peace.
The recent protests, while ostensibly against Hasina's regime, have taken on a dangerous communal turn with increased attacks on the Hindu minority.
Addressing this violence and ensuring the safety of minorities is a top priority for Yunus. The task is further complicated by the absence of the Awami League, Hasina's party, from the interim government. Yunus must now find ways to engage all stakeholders, including the Awami League, to heal the nation's wounds. Bangladesh needs stability and unity, and the onus is on Yunus to guide the country through this turbulent period.

item.title: Kolkata doctor’s rape and murder shows how we fail women — yet again
item.description:
Two recent incidents highlight the persistent issue of women's safety in India. The death of a trainee doctor in Kolkata after a sexual assault and the lifelong vegetative state of Aruna Shanbaug, assaulted decades ago, underscore the failure to adequately protect women, despite pronouncements of female empowerment.
The death in Kolkata exposes inadequate security measures within medical institutions, including a lack of on-call rooms and malfunctioning CCTV cameras. The widespread underutilization of the Nirbhaya Fund, established after the 2012 Delhi gangrape, further illustrates the disconnect between promises and action. While demanding justice is crucial, the focus should be on addressing the systemic issues that perpetuate violence against women, ensuring safe workplaces, and fulfilling commitments to equality.

item.title: C Raja Mohan writes: Bangladesh and the ‘foreign hand’ bogey
item.description:
The article critiques the theory that a US-backed coup orchestrated by Muhammad Yunus ousted Sheikh Hasina from power in Bangladesh. It argues that this conspiracy theory ignores the real reasons behind Hasina's downfall, namely her own political missteps and growing unpopularity.
The author points out that Hasina’s authoritarian tendencies, rigged elections, and economic mismanagement created anti-regime sentiment, which culminated in the student movement’s protests.
The article further argues that attributing Hasina's loss solely to external forces reflects a failure of Indian strategic thinking and overlooks the complexities of Bangladeshi politics. It suggests that India should instead focus on cooperating with the new Bangladeshi government while supporting the democratic aspirations of the student movement.
The author acknowledges Hasina's significant contributions to Bangladesh's development and her strong relationship with India. Finally, they emphasize the need for continued collaboration between India and the US in the region, especially given the current political instability in Bangladesh and Myanmar.

item.title: UPSC aspirants don’t need coaching classes to succeed. Here’s my story
item.description:
The article discusses the allure and exploitation within India's competitive Civil Services Examination (CSE) ecosystem, specifically focusing on Old Rajinder Nagar (ORN) in Delhi. The author, an IAS officer, recounts their personal experience moving to ORN and enrolling in a costly coaching institute, realizing the exorbitant fees provided no better value compared to readily available resources.
The article criticizes the coaching industry's overhyped promises and exploitation of aspiring candidates, particularly those from less privileged backgrounds. Social media further amplifies this, with staged mock interviews presented as authentic representations of the CSE process. The author highlights the harsh living conditions in ORN, coupled with unrealistic expectations fueled by profit-driven institutions.
The article concludes with a call to action, urging aspirants to rely on official UPSC guidelines and resources, questioning the narratives surrounding coaching institutes and popular locations. It emphasizes the importance of individual dedication and original thinking over external pressures.

item.title: In his centenary year, making sense of Guru Dutt in the classroom
item.description: This article explores the use of Guru Dutt's film "Pyaasa" as a parallel to Plato's "Allegory of the Cave" in a Creative Writing classroom. The author compares Dutt's portrayal of a neglected poet, Vijay, with the prisoners in the cave who mistake shadows for reality. Vijay's rejection by society mirrors the prisoners' inability to perceive true reality beyond the confines of their cave. The article argues that both Plato and Dutt challenge conventional thinking, prompting audiences to question the nature of truth and the influence of power structures. By showcasing Vijay's poignant song, "yeh duniya agar mil bhi jaaye toh kya hai," the author emphasizes the importance of art and introspection over material wealth and societal validation. Ultimately, the article advocates for a more philosophical approach to creative writing that encourages deep contemplation and questioning of societal norms.

item.title: To understand what’s going on in Bangladesh, look at its past, army and society
item.description:
The recent instability in Bangladesh is a result of deep-seated fault lines within the country.
These include a conflict between secularism, Islamic identity, and Bengali popular culture. Historical divisions stemming from the 1971 War of Liberation, particularly regarding India's role, further exacerbate tensions. Public perception of India is often negative, influenced by propaganda and a belief that India's support came at a cost.
Bangladesh also struggles with unstable civil-military relations. The military's involvement in commercial activities and its politicization create a sense of unease. These internal divisions contribute to the current turmoil, including attacks on minorities and the government's inability to effectively manage the situation.

item.title: August 13, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Tamil Extremists Held
item.description: A powerful explosion destroyed the Chunnakam police station near Jaffna, Sri Lanka, killing at least 19 suspected Tamil extremists. The blast occurred when a group attempted to free Tamil youths arrested during security operations, triggering a booby trap.

item.title: The songs of Haniya: A confident music
item.description:
Haniya Aslam, one half of the Pakistani folk duo, known for her first all-woman music group "Chup", passed away due to a cardiac arrest. Aslam, along with her cousin Zebunissa Bangash, gained popularity on Coke Studio Pakistan for their modernized interpretations of traditional Dari folk songs.
Their album "Chup" went beyond borders with its internet reach, paving the way for their unique blend of Afghan rabab and Pakistani acoustic guitar to find global resonance. After the duo disbanded, Aslam pursued audio engineering in Canada and upon her return to Pakistan released "Main Irada", an empowering anthem for women.

item.title: Centre’s waiver for clinical trials: For the patient’s sake
item.description:
The Indian government recently waived clinical trials for certain drug categories approved in developed nations, aiming to expedite access to innovative therapies like those for Alzheimer's, cancer, and autoimmune disorders. This move could benefit both patients and pharmaceutical companies by reducing costs and timelines.
However, ensuring affordability remains crucial. The government should consider expanding healthcare safety nets and exploring state procurement of novel drugs to minimize the financial burden on patients. Promoting domestic research through incentives and ease of business is also essential, as India aims to move beyond its generic drug stronghold and contribute to developing new drug molecules.

item.title: A Bangladesh without Sheikh Hasina, a reset for Delhi
item.description:
The recent political change in Bangladesh, leading to the establishment of an interim government, presents both challenges and opportunities for the region. India has historically maintained a policy of non-interference in Bangladesh's internal affairs. Despite disagreements over border killings and water sharing, India and Bangladesh have made significant progress in strengthening bilateral ties in recent years, encompassing areas like security, trade, and energy.
Bangladesh's remarkable socio-economic development and successes in sectors like microfinance have been commended by India. Moving forward, both nations need to address outstanding issues through cooperation and diplomacy, focusing on shared challenges like poverty, unemployment, and climate change. The hope is for a future marked by mutual trust and progress, building on the foundations laid in recent years.

item.title: In Manish Sisodia case, Supreme Court shows the way
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruled that the right to a speedy trial is a fundamental right protected by Article 21 of the Constitution. This decision, while not introducing new legal principles, carries significant weight as the Court acted upon its stated position and clarified its application within the context of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA).
The judgement, which freed Manish Sisodia after 17 months in jail, highlights the Court's criticism of both the state and the judiciary for delays in trials. The Court emphasized that bail is the rule and imprisonment the exception, urging lower courts to adhere to this principle and considering the length of incarceration without trial. The case underscores the importance of safeguarding individual liberty and ensuring that legal proceedings are conducted fairly and expeditiously.

item.title: Express View: Monsoon and the good news for inflation
item.description:
This year's southwest monsoon season started weakly but recovered significantly in July and August, resulting in a 6.3% surplus in cumulative rainfall. The well-distributed rains have positively impacted kharif crop sowing areas.
With favorable weather conditions, the upcoming rabi cropping season also appears promising. The surplus monsoon and absence of heat waves are expected to ease food inflation, which has been a concern for the past few months. This could allow the government to ease restrictions on exports and stock limits for cereals, sugar, and pulses.

item.title: Hindenburg revelations raise questions — Sebi and its chief Madhabi Puri Buch must answer
item.description: The article discusses concerns regarding potential conflicts of interest concerning the current chairperson of Sebi, Madhabi Puri Buch. The author highlights revelations by Hindenburg Research about Buch and her husband's investments in an offshore fund linked to the Adani Group. The article raises questions about Buch's transparency and recusal from investigations involving the group, given her personal financial ties. It emphasizes the importance of both institutional autonomy and personal integrity in a market regulator, suggesting that Buch's disclosures should have gone beyond Sebi's board to include the Supreme Court and a committee examining regulatory failures related to the Adani Group.

item.title: Tariq Mansoor writes: Why fears around Waqf Amendment Bill are exaggerated
item.description:
The Waqf Amendment Bill, 2024 has sparked anxiety within a section of the Muslim community. However, it's important to analyze the proposal objectively as this is not the first time the waqf law is being amended. Previous amendments in 1913, 1930, 1995, and 2013, along with recommendations from the Sachar Committee and a Joint Parliamentary Committee, highlight that reforms to waqf administration have been a long-standing concern.
The government has received numerous grievances from Muslims regarding waqf property encroachments, mismanagement, and delays in registration. Furthermore, the vast potential of waqf properties for socio-economic development, considering their status as public institutions and the largest landholders after Railways and Defence, necessitates improvements in their administration. International examples such as Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and others demonstrate the successful regulation and public engagement with waqf properties by governments.
Therefore, the debate on waqf reforms should be based on facts, experience, and a commitment to social justice and gender equity.

item.title: Antitrust deja vu: Ruling against Google is reminiscent of a similar one against Microsoft in 2001
item.description:
The author reflects on Microsoft's historical monopolistic practices, referencing a 2001 ruling against the company for leveraging its dominance in the OS market to stifle browser competition. Drawing parallels to the recent antitrust ruling against Google, the author argues that despite legal challenges, technology giants like Microsoft and Google have deeply ingrained themselves in our digital lives, making it difficult to dislodge them.
The author contends that in emerging markets, access to technology is often facilitated through piracy, a factor not adequately addressed by anti-competition law. Ultimately, the author suggests that the future threat to Google's dominance may not come from competing search engines but from the emergence of generative AI.

item.title: Mani Shankar Aiyar writes: Natwar Singh, friend, patron and man of many parts
item.description:
K Natwar Singh, a prominent figure in India's Foreign Service, transitioned seamlessly into politics, becoming the External Affairs Minister. Known for his strong connections with influential figures, including the Nehru-Gandhis and literary personalities, he navigated international relations with finesse. Serving as India's representative at the UN Decolonisation Committee fostered enduring bonds with African freedom fighters.
His diplomatic career was marked by both accolades and controversies, including an "out-of-turn" posting to Warsaw and a subsequent "punishment posting" to Zambia. Despite setbacks, he remained steadfast in his principles, publicly condemning the 1980 Moradabad Eidgah police firing.
Natwar's political journey saw him part ways with the Congress after the Volcker Committee report, choosing to leave behind the political arena. He remained a close friend and mentor, offering guidance and support to those around him. His legacy as a diplomat, politician, and friend endures.

item.title: August 12, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Sarbat khalsa meets
item.description: The Sarbat Khalsa convention held the SGPC and its president G S Tohra accountable for the damage to the Golden Temple. Tohra was excommunicated from the Khalsa panth. The convention also called for significant changes to the Sikh Gurdwara Act to ensure the respect and position of Sikh sahibans.

item.title: Why the real victory for Phogat’s fight against power does not lie in a medal
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's journey to the Paris Olympics mirrored Rocky's determination, with her striving to "go the distance" both in the ring and against systemic injustices. Her fight for justice extended beyond her personal experience, resonating with countless women who saw their own struggles in her battle against the Wrestling Federation of India president, who was accused of sexual assault.
While her historic win against the defending champion was a significant victory, her subsequent disqualification sparked outrage and highlighted the cultural challenges women face in India. Her story transcends a simple quest for a medal, representing a broader struggle for dignity and recognition. While a medal can serve as consolation, the real challenge lies in dismantling the systems that perpetuate injustice and empower women to pursue their dreams without facing undue burdens.

item.title: Vinesh Phogat is the success story Indians need to hear
item.description: Vinesh Phogat's journey to success is a potent symbol of overcoming adversity. Despite facing significant challenges and alleged injustice, she shines as a role model, her achievements particularly inspiring in a society grappling with inequality. However, it's crucial to acknowledge the struggles many encounter on their paths to success, the hurdles, and the often-unfair expectations placed upon them. Her story, while inspiring, should also prompt reflection on the systemic issues that contribute to these difficulties and the need for greater support and opportunity for all. We must celebrate triumphs while remaining aware of the broader context and addressing the root causes of inequality.

item.title: On Bangladesh, Maldives and Afghanistan, why was India taken by surprise?
item.description:
Recent political shifts in Afghanistan and neighboring South Asian countries like Bangladesh and Maldives have dealt a blow to India's foreign policy interests. These unexpected changes raise questions about whether India's foreign policy and security establishments were adequately prepared or caught unaware.
India's National Security structure has evolved significantly since 1998, with the establishment of bodies like the National Security Council and National Security Advisor (NSA). These institutions aim to coordinate strategic and security functions. However, concerns have been raised about potential "turf" issues between different agencies and the influence of these issues on decision-making. There's a need to scrutinize whether the failures stem from structural inadequacies, misjudgments, or both.

item.title: Express View: After the Olympics
item.description:
India's Olympic performance in Paris saw a decline in the medal tally, finishing with six medals compared to seven at the previous Games. The absence of a gold medal, particularly with defending champion Neeraj Chopra only securing silver, impacted the country's overall ranking.
There's a call for introspection and collaborative efforts from stakeholders, including federations, the Sports Authority of India, and the Sports Ministry, to analyze weaknesses and improve strategies.
The performance of the men's hockey team, securing back-to-back bronze medals, was highlighted as a success, attributed to a consistent core group, experienced coach, and supportive management.
The review emphasizes the importance of identifying and supporting champions effectively, listening to their needs and providing them with the necessary resources.

item.title: Express View on Hindenburg report: A cloud over SEBI
item.description: Hindenburg Research has accused SEBI chairperson Madhabi Puri Buch of having undisclosed financial interests in offshore funds linked to the Adani Group, raising questions about potential conflicts of interest and regulatory inaction. Hindenburg alleges Buch's husband held stakes in the same funds and that she communicated with their managers while serving on SEBI's board. Buch maintains she has fulfilled all disclosure requirements. Critics question why these disclosures were not made public during the investigation into the Adani Group, especially considering the importance of transparency in financial regulation. The controversy has heightened scrutiny of SEBI's independence and its handling of the Adani case. Calls for a thorough investigation and full disclosure emphasize the need to protect the integrity of the regulator and restore public trust.

item.title: Vandita Mishra writes: Ahead of Independence Day
item.description:
This Independence Day, India faces a crucial moment for its democracy. The recent electoral result, which significantly reduced the ruling party's majority, has underscored the importance of safeguarding democratic values.
The government, accustomed to unchallenged authority, is now encountering a more assertive opposition, demanding greater accountability and freedom from perceived arrogance. This new dynamic is forcing the government to adapt and engage in a less centralized and more transparent manner, as evidenced by the referral of a controversial bill to a parliamentary committee.
However, challenges remain. Instances of partisan behavior from the ruling side, a hardening stance on religious autonomy, and the use of legal provisions to target political opponents raise concerns about backsliding on democratic norms. Simultaneously, the judiciary's recent bail decision for a senior opposition leader offers a glimmer of hope for an independent institution acting as a check on governmental power.
India continues to strive for a balance between its democratic traditions and the evolving political landscape.

item.title: SC, ST sub-quotas will not break Dalit unity
item.description:
The Supreme Court's decision to allow sub-classification within Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe reservations has sparked controversy.
While some sections within Scheduled Castes criticize the verdict, arguing it undermines unity, advocates for sub-classification highlight the need to address the historically marginalized communities who have been left behind.
The debate raises questions about the true extent of inclusivity within Dalit leadership and the sincerity of claims to represent all Dalit communities.
The Supreme Court's ruling is seen as exposing those who prioritize their own advancement over the collective upliftment of all Dalits.

item.title: Kolkata doctor’s murder: National Medical Commission must step up
item.description:
The recent death of a resident doctor in Kolkata, allegedly due to sexual assault and strangulation, has brought to light the grave safety concerns and hazardous working conditions faced by resident doctors in India. This incident follows a pattern of violence and harassment against doctors, including the murder of Vandana Das in Kerala and the suicide of Payal Salim Tadvi in Mumbai due to alleged harassment.
Resident doctors face multiple threats, from competitive exams and high fees to abuse by seniors, violence from patients, and risks of sexual assault. The lack of adequate duty rooms, safe living spaces, and effective grievance redressal mechanisms exacerbates these challenges. Data reveals a concerning rise in suicides among resident doctors and students, highlighting the urgent need for systemic changes to ensure their safety, well-being, and dignity.

item.title: Sanjay Srivastava writes: For a nation that aspires to Olympic glory, what is the role of the state?
item.description: The article discusses whether India's state should fund elite sports. The author argues against state involvement, highlighting the lack of public benefit and the potential for abuse and corruption within the current sporting system. They point to a lack of connection between elite sporting success and public welfare, and suggest that private investment might be more effective in driving medals, albeit for profit-oriented reasons. The author suggests that instead, public funds should be directed towards areas like education, healthcare, and housing for the most deprived, arguing that a more realistic understanding of the state's role is needed.

item.title: Let’s call a meeting
item.description:
The Delhi government has shifted from traditional cabinet meetings to a more streamlined process of circulating cabinet notes. This has led to a higher number of decisions being made through notes rather than physical meetings, which proponents argue expedites policy implementation. The article then explores the broader trend of increasing workplace efficiency through technology, raising questions about the potential downsides of reduced human interaction in offices and daily life.
It argues that face-to-face interactions are crucial for building relationships, fostering a sense of community, and exploring life's possibilities. The piece cites examples of technology replacing human connection in various aspects of life, drawing parallels to the themes of loneliness and isolation presented in the movie Her.

item.title: Inside Track: Total segregation
item.description: The new Parliament building in India has been designed with separation in mind, dividing journalists, Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha MPs, and former MPs from current ones. This division extends to separate cafeterias and limited access for former MPs. The Congress party views Rahul Gandhi's newfound popularity after his recent yatras as a positive sign for the 2024 elections, with some allies even suggesting he could be the "PM-in-waiting." However, not all allies are convinced. Meanwhile, newly appointed Madhya Pradesh CM Mohan Yadav is actively working to enhance his public image and promote himself through social media and interviews, even potentially leveraging the success of his predecessor, Shivraj Singh Chouhan.

item.title: Tavleen Singh writes: Lessons from Bangladesh
item.description:
The article analyzes the recent political upheaval in Bangladesh, where Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was forced to flee. It draws parallels to the suppression of dissent in India, particularly under the current government's leadership. The author argues that labeling dissent as treason, exemplified by the terms "urban Naxals" and the rhetoric against Muslim protestors, is a dangerous trend that undermines India's democratic foundations.
The article also criticizes the historical erosion of democratic freedoms in India, starting with the first amendment to the Constitution, and highlights the risks posed by a government that prioritizes economic growth over political autonomy. Ultimately, the author urges India to learn from Bangladesh's experience and safeguard its democratic principles to remain a beacon of democracy in a region dominated by autocratic regimes.

item.title: 100 years ago, when a train robbery shook the Empire
item.description:
The Kakori case involved the audacious robbery of British treasury money by the Hindustan Republican Association (HRA) in 1925. Led by revolutionaries like Ram Prasad Bismil and Ashfaqullah Khan, the action shook the British Raj but also resulted in the death of a passenger, harming their cause. Nineteen individuals were convicted, with Bismil, Lahiri, Ashfaqullah Khan, and Roshan Singh facing death sentences. Chandrashekhar Azad, another key figure associated with the HRA, evaded capture and died during a police confrontation in 1931.
The case had wider ramifications, impacting political figures and sparking debate for decades. It highlights the daring fight for independence and the complex legacy of revolution in India.

item.title: P Chidambaram writes: Democracy deficit
item.description:
This article discusses the fragility of democracy and the consequences of its decline. It uses examples like Bangladesh, Pakistan, and the United States to illustrate how economic progress does not guarantee democratic values. The article highlights the dangers of a "democracy deficit," where citizens lose faith in fair elections and turn to street protests, which can have disastrous consequences. It argues that a healthy democracy needs strong institutions like an independent judiciary, a free press, and regular, fair elections.
The author suggests several measures to address democracy deficits, including term limits, resignation clauses for leaders facing discontent, and a vibrant parliamentary debate. The article concludes by expressing sadness over the loss of life in Bangladeshi protests, emphasizing the high cost of neglecting democratic principles.

item.title: Half-truths and twisted facts about the RSS
item.description:
The article defends the Modi government's decision to lift the ban on government employees participating in RSS activities. It argues that this action, along with other measures, is part of decolonizing India.
The author criticizes Pawan Khera's article, claiming it distorts history by ignoring the Nehru government's alleged persecution of the RSS and highlighting Nehru's personal animosity towards the organization. It also points to Sardar Patel's views on the RSS, asserting that he considered it a patriotic organization.
The article further challenges Khera's accusations of undue favoritism towards the RSS, drawing attention to the Rajiv Gandhi Foundation's acceptance of funds from various sources including the Chinese government. It concludes by drawing a contrast between the Congress's past and present, suggesting Rahul Gandhi's party has adopted a more leftist and adversarial stance.

item.title: Olympic gold medallist Arshad Nadeem and the hurdles for Pakistani athletes
item.description:
Pakistan celebrated a historic moment when Arshad Nadeem secured the country's first Olympic gold medal in javelin throw since 1984. Nadeem's victory, achieved despite limited resources and funding, has sparked calls for increased government support for athletes.
The fifth anniversary of the abrogation of Article 370 in Jammu and Kashmir was marked by renewed debate. Pakistan condemned India's move, highlighting the need for a dialogue to resolve the Kashmir issue. In the UK, a stabbing incident at a dance studio, initially linked to a Muslim immigrant, fueled Islamophobia and prompted concerns about the rise of far-right sentiments.
Protests in Bangladesh over job quotas led to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fleeing to India, raising questions about the stability of the Bangladeshi government and its implications for regional dynamics.

item.title: From the ground at Paris Olympics, a question: What will it take for India to become a sporting nation?
item.description:
The article discusses India's rise in international hockey, analyzing the factors contributing to the team's success. While acknowledging the improvement in sporting infrastructure and talent development, the author emphasizes the importance of a deeper understanding and appreciation of sports among the general public.
Drawing from her experience watching the Olympics, the author highlights the German fans' informed and analytical approach to the game. She contrasts this with the tendency in India to either idolize or criticize athletes without a nuanced understanding of the sport itself.
Ultimately, the author argues that for India to become a true sporting nation, citizens need to engage with sports beyond simply cheering for their teams. Experiencing and understanding the nuances of various sports will foster a deeper respect for athletes and contribute to a more informed and supportive sporting culture.

item.title: Prabhat Patnaik writes on Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee: A communist first
item.description: Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee's involvement in communist politics stemmed from the vibrant intellectual and cultural environment of Bengal, combined with the party's strong organizational structure and commitment to land reforms. As part of the Left Front government, he played a crucial role in implementing policies that addressed economic disparity, strengthened participatory democracy, and boosted agricultural growth. However, his later decision to attract private industrial investment, a departure from the party's traditional stance, led to alienation of the peasantry and ultimately contributed to the Left Front's decline. Despite this, Buddhadev Bhattacharjee's legacy remains significant for his championing of land rights, fostering grassroots politics, and promoting dialogue with internal resident groups through autonomous councils.

item.title: SC/ST Sub-quota red lines and red herrings
item.description:
The recent Supreme Court verdict on sub-quotas within the Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST) reservations has sparked debate.
Supporters of social justice argue that the verdict, while seemingly concerning diluting reservation, actually strengthens affirmative action by focusing on the needs of the most disadvantaged communities within these categories. Some criticisms against the ruling, focused on legal and political grounds, are deemed inaccurate and lacking evidence.
The article highlights specific concerns regarding the potential misuse of sub-classification for political gains and the unintended consequences of applying the "creamy layer" doctrine to SCs and STs.
It suggests focusing on addressing these flaws in the judgment rather than rejecting the notion of sub-quotas altogether. Long-term solutions, such as enhancing reservation percentages, removing the 50% ceiling, and broadening the scope of social justice initiatives beyond public sector jobs, are also emphasized. Ultimately, the article urges a nuanced discussion that addresses the complexities of the verdict and its implications.

item.title: Ram Madhav writes: In Bangladesh, it’s time for healing
item.description: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's long-serving prime minister, recently faced unprecedented protests from young citizens due to economic hardships and unrest triggered by the reinstatement of a controversial quota system for government jobs. Despite Bangladesh's significant economic growth under Hasina, inequality widened, unemployment rose, and cost of living soared, leading to resentment among the youth. Protests, initially against the quota system, escalated into a larger movement against Hasina's government. The government's heavy-handed response, labels the protests as "terrorism," and deployment of the ruling party's student wing against agitating students further inflamed the situation.

item.title: Menaka Guruswamy writes on Manish Sisodia’s bail: A victory for right to life, liberty
item.description:
The Supreme Court granted bail to Manish Sisodia, former Delhi deputy Chief Minister, after he spent over a year and a half in jail without conviction. The court emphasized that bail is the norm and jail an exception, highlighting the importance of speedy trials to uphold the right to life and liberty.
The judgment also states that the right to bail should be considered in cases of significant delay coupled with prolonged incarceration. The court expects trial courts and High Courts to adhere to the "bail is the rule, jail is the exception" principle while considering bail applications under both the CrPC and PMLA. This comes as the right to bail faces pressure, particularly in money laundering cases.
The court acknowledged the state's assurance that the trial would be concluded within 6-8 months, but also recognized the impracticality of such a timeline given the volume of witnesses and documents. The judgment underscores the importance of sharing all relevant evidence, including potentially exculpatory material, to ensure a fair trial.

item.title: SC verdict on subclassification of caste-based reservation will worsen reality of the Dalit community. Here’s why
item.description:
The Supreme Court's verdict allowing sub-classification within Scheduled Castes/Scheduled Tribes and introducing a creamy layer concept is highly problematic. The judgment ignores the severe social realities faced by a vast majority of Dalits who struggle for basic survival and are unable to benefit from reservation. The court overlooks the fact that government posts reserved for SCs/STs remain vacant due to a lack of eligible candidates, often cited as a consequence of systemic disadvantages.
Equating the OBC creamy layer with Dalit exclusion from reservation is illogical given the distinct social and economic positions of the two groups. Sub-classifying Dalits will only exacerbate existing inequalities and create further division.
The judgment disregards the persistent social stigma and "camouflaged untouchability" faced by Dalits, regardless of their economic status, which remains a primary justification for reservation. The court's decision also violates constitutional provisions that clearly define the process for identifying Scheduled Castes and prohibits any subsequent modifications.

item.title: Express View: Delhi must reach out to Dhaka
item.description:
The author believes that India's continued support for the new leadership in Bangladesh is crucial to prevent further instability. While highlighting the importance of protecting minority rights, particularly the Hindu community, the author urges India to avoid focusing solely on this issue, which could complicate relations.
The author suggests that India should understand the student-led revolution in Bangladesh, engage with its leaders, and review its own policies that failed to anticipate the political turmoil. They emphasize that Bangladesh is not "India's to lose" but "India's to win" through constructive engagement, emphasizing the need for India to shed any illusions of regional hegemony and build genuine support through diplomacy and economic cooperation. Despite the current crisis, the author expresses optimism about the resilience of India-Bangladesh relations, with strategic patience and empathy playing key roles in navigating the situation.

item.title: Express View: Neeraj Chopra, soaring high
item.description: Despite a season-best throw, Neeraj Chopra won silver in Paris, falling short of defending his Tokyo gold. This achievement, nonetheless, cements his place as one of India's greatest track and field athletes, joining an exclusive club of only two others who have won Olympic medals in consecutive Games. Chopra's performance was remarkable considering recurring groin pain from a previous injury. At 26, Chopra is approaching peak performance and has his sights set on breaking the 90-meter mark. His primary competitor? Arshad Nadeem, a fellow javelin thrower from Pakistan. Their rivalry, born out of mutual respect and competition, promises to be a highlight in the years to come.

item.title: August 10, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Bomb blast probe
item.description:
A bomb blast at Meenambakkam airport in India killed 29 people and injured 38. The Tourism and Civil Aviation Minister acknowledged that airport and police officials did not appropriately respond to the bomb threat.
Authorities are pursuing useful leads from the investigation.
Meanwhile, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi addressed rumors of Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale's survival, assuring the nation that he was indeed dead.
On the international stage, India's P T Usha narrowly missed a bronze medal in the 400 meter hurdles at the Los Angeles Olympic Games.

item.title: Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore and the zero gravity life
item.description: Astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore will remain on the International Space Station (ISS) longer than expected due to technical issues with their Boeing Starliner spacecraft. Their scheduled eight-day mission has been extended to February 2025, when they will return to Earth on a SpaceX Crew Dragon. While they continue with experiments and maintenance tasks on the ISS, the delay highlights the ongoing challenges in making space travel readily accessible to the public, despite advancements in technology.

item.title: Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee and his dreams for West Bengal
item.description: Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee, a highly principled leader, was deeply influential through his persona, words, and writings. His political career was marked by a strong anti-imperialist stance and a commitment to Bengal's cultural heritage. He championed democratic values, secularism, and scientific temper. As a Minister and Chief Minister, he significantly revitalized Bengal's cultural landscape through initiatives like the Calcutta Book Fair and Film Festival. He also spearheaded industrialization efforts to combat brain drain and promote job creation. Bhattacharjee was a visionary who dedicated his life to serving the people of West Bengal. His loss is deeply felt by those who witnessed his unwavering commitment and transformative leadership.

item.title: With Vinesh Phogat’s disqualification, questions for the government
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's disqualification from the gold-medal wrestling bout at the Paris Olympics has sparked widespread outrage in India. The incident is viewed as more than just a lost medal, as Phogat represents the struggle of Indian sportswomen against sexual abuse within the Wrestling Federation of India.
Phogat and other wrestlers bravely exposed allegations against the then-WFI president, Brij Bhushan Singh, leading to a prolonged battle for justice. Despite facing backlash and hostility, Phogat persevered and achieved remarkable success in the Olympics.
Her disqualification, however, has raised serious questions about the fairness of the system and the government's handling of the situation. The public is demanding answers and accountability, highlighting a larger issue of systemic injustice faced by athletes, especially women.

item.title: Jai-Veeru in an inspirational postcard
item.description:
Neeraj Chopra and Arshad Nadeem, javelin throwers from India and Pakistan respectively, exemplify sportsmanship and friendship despite the historical and political tensions between their countries.
Neeraj's graciousness towards Arshad after winning an Olympic gold in 2021 and Arshad later winning the gold in 2024 while Neeraj secured the silver, showcases their camaraderie. Their bond stands as a positive example in a world often divided by political and social barriers. Their story celebrates the unifying power of sports and the strength of human connection, reminding us that compassion and empathy transcend national boundaries.

item.title: August 9, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Yet another failed Opposition bid for unity
item.description:
Indira Gandhi urged restraint in India's response to the Sri Lankan situation, emphasizing the need to protect Tamils. An attempt to merge Lok Dal, Janata, and Congress (S) failed, with the parties unable to agree on a merger.
Parliamentarians expressed concern over rising communal riots, calling for government action to curb the violence. Vishwanath Pratap Singh was appointed president of the Uttar Pradesh PCC(I) to strengthen the Congress (I) organization ahead of elections.

item.title: Dear Lakshya, to me, you will always be a winner
item.description:
The author expresses their pride in Lakshya Sen's accomplishments at the Paris tournament.
They recount their emotional experience watching his matches, highlighting both his victories and the heartbreak of his injury and subsequent loss. The author draws parallels between Sen's experience and their daughter's passion for football, emphasizing the shared emotional investment in sports. They move on to reflect on the collective disappointment felt by Indians following the tournament's other results, including Vinesh Phogat's disqualification.
Though acknowledging the losses, the author concludes by praising the resilience and determination of Indian athletes, urging them onward with a message of hope and support.

item.title: How uncertainty of food inflation affects RBI’s policy going forward
item.description:
The RBI Monetary Policy Committee has kept policy rates unchanged, acknowledging market expectations but noting uncertainty about future actions. Food inflation, a significant component of the CPI basket, remains elevated due to climatic factors. While core inflation is subdued, high food prices impact household expectations, complicating the RBI's policy stance.
The RBI aims for a 4% CPI inflation target, but food inflation volatility poses a challenge. A strong monsoon may moderate food prices, but achieving the target remains a challenge. The RBI projects average FY25 inflation at 4.5%, with growth anticipated at 7.2%.
Global economic conditions are uncertain, with geo-political tensions and monetary policy divergence among countries. The RBI is monitoring bank deposit growth and credit risk, noting the diversion of household savings towards other asset classes. The RBI is likely to assess food inflation trends and could consider a shallow rate cut later in the year if food inflation moderates.

item.title: 25 years of ‘The Blair Witch Project’: All that is lost — and found — online
item.description:
The Blair Witch Project, released in 1999, ingeniously blurred the lines between fact and fiction, capitalizing on the early internet's naivety. The film's "found footage" style, supported by a persuasive online campaign featuring fabricated evidence, created an unsettling ambiguity for viewers.
Nowadays, the internet's evolution, marked by the prevalence of "found footage" tropes and the proliferation of deepfakes, has made such deception less effective. What was once a simple affirmation of trust in online information has become a cautionary reminder of the dangers of believing everything encountered online.

item.title: RBI’s interest rates remain unchanged. But food inflation will guide policy path
item.description:
The RBI maintained its interest rates and focus on withdrawing accommodation in its August meeting. While headline inflation rose to 5.08% in June due to food price surges, the RBI anticipates moderation in the second quarter, projecting full year inflation at 4.5%.
Growth prospects remain strong, enabling the MPC to prioritize inflation control. High food inflation, particularly in cereals, pulses, and vegetables, poses a risk of fueling household inflation expectations and potentially spilling over to core inflation.
Despite this, core inflation remains subdued, encouraging the RBI's continued disinflationary stance. Global trends suggest that central banks are considering interest rate cuts, but the RBI awaits further clarity on food inflation's trajectory before making policy adjustments at its October meeting.

item.title: Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee, the rooted, Bhadralok communist
item.description: Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee, a former chief minister of West Bengal, passed away on August 8th. He was known for his political activism during turbulent times and his role in the Left Front government. Bhattacharjee was a strong advocate for industrial growth and a figure who appealed to both the middle class and the urban elite. He also faced criticism for his handling of protests and his perceived arrogance. His personal life saw him wrestling with the temptations of power and corporate influence, struggling to remain true to his communist ideals throughout his career.

item.title: Express View on Buddhadeb Bhattacharya: The tragic reformer
item.description:
Buddhadeb Bhattacharya, the last Left chief minister of West Bengal, championed a blend of communist ideology and economic liberalization. He sought to modernize the state's infrastructure and attract investment through projects like the SEZ in Nandigram and the Nano plant in Singur.
However, his vision was challenged by a rigid party structure resistant to change, and his attempts at reform were ultimately overshadowed by the controversial land acquisition protests in Nandigram. While he is remembered for his progressive stance and contributions to cinema and culture, his legacy is marked by the decline of the CPM in West Bengal, a decline he deeply regretted.

item.title: Buddhadeb Bhattacharya: Communist who saw the future
item.description:
Buddhadeb Bhattacharya, a prominent figure in West Bengal's political landscape, passed away after a long illness. Known as Buddhada, he rose to prominence through student activism and youth leadership in the late 1960s. He played a key role in the Left Front's success, serving as MLA and a minister in Jyoti Basu's government. As chief minister from 2000 to 2011, he focused on industrial growth while upholding socialist principles of economic and social justice.
Buddhada was known for his modest lifestyle, commitment to democracy, and engagement with diverse voices. Despite electoral setbacks, he remained steadfast in his convictions, leaving behind a legacy of progressive leadership and inspiration for younger generations in West Bengal.

item.title: Vinesh Phogat and athletes ‘weight cutting’ — why they do it and the health dangers
item.description: Weight management in sports, particularly wrestling, involves careful strategies to fit within weight categories. Athletes often employ extreme measures to shed weight before competitions, such as excessive workouts, fasting, and dehydration. This practice, while effective for short-term weight loss, can be detrimental to an athlete's health, leading to muscle loss, injury, and psychological issues. The weight-loss methods commonly employed can lead athletes into a catabolic state, where their bodies begin breaking down muscle for energy. Despite the risks, athletes continue to engage in these practices to gain a competitive advantage. The case of Vinesh Phogat, who narrowly missed her weight limit, highlights the potential for complications and the delicate balance between training and health.

item.title: India is still some way from achieving universal health coverage. Here’s why
item.description:
The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), launched in 2018, aimed to improve healthcare coverage for India's poorest population. An analysis of recent household expenditure survey data shows that while coverage of public health insurance programs increased for the poorest population quintiles since 2018, it remains low, with less than 30% covered. Furthermore, the utilization of public health insurance among covered individuals remains low. The data also reveals that while the burden of out-of-pocket expenditure (OOPE) for inpatient care has decreased for the poorest populations, they still incur significant costs.
Despite some progress, the survey indicates that India is still lagging in achieving Universal Health Coverage through targeted public health insurance. Key challenges remain in expanding coverage to the intended beneficiaries and ensuring robust financial protection, particularly for the poorest populations.

item.title: Reducing the poor’s health burden
item.description:
This analysis examines the vulnerability of India's bottom 50% population to medical shocks, particularly hospitalisation, using data from the Household Consumption Expenditure Survey (HCES) 2022-23.
It reveals a positive trend: the proportion of households experiencing hospitalisation has increased, indicating improved healthcare access. Interestingly, while overall health expenditure has risen slightly for households without hospitalisation, the share consumed by hospitalisation has declined significantly. This suggests hospitalisation is becoming more affordable.
Furthermore, the analysis shows a decrease in the likelihood of households facing a decline in consumption status due to hospitalisation costs. This improvement is particularly pronounced in rural areas and for households with young children and elderly members. The study attributes these positive developments to public health policies like Ayushman Bharat Yojana, aimed at mitigating the financial burden of hospitalisation for the poor.

item.title: Why accusations of witchcraft persist in India
item.description:
India is grappling with an issue of witch-hunting, despite strides in development. While global awareness of the problem is increasing, India faces a unique challenge. Though most incidents occur in rural areas, witch-hunting remains a serious concern, documented by the NCRB.
Between 2009 and 2019, the UN recorded 20,000 cases of harmful witch-related practices across 60 countries, including India. Despite various state-specific laws aiming to combat this practice, implementation remains a challenge.
Low prosecution rates, lenient penalties, and a lack of clarity regarding the intent of the legislation hinder effective action. The issue requires a multifaceted approach, encompassing education, awareness campaigns, and reforms within the criminal justice system. It also demands a clear distinction between the practice of witchcraft and the accusation of witchcraft, which often leads to violence and persecution.

item.title: August 8, 1984, Forty Years Ago: P T Usha’s Dream Run
item.description: PT Usha made history at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics by becoming the first Indian woman to qualify for the 400-meter hurdles final. She achieved a career-best time of 55.54 seconds in the second semi-final heat. Meanwhile, talks between India and Pakistan have been postponed indefinitely, unlikely to resume before the Indian elections. Sri Lankan authorities launched a major security crackdown in Jaffna, resulting in numerous arrests and deaths.

item.title: The 25-hour day – don’t waste if on ‘productivity’
item.description: A future study predicts that the Moon's gradual movement away from Earth will lengthen our days to 25 hours in millions of years.
