This extra hour could be a valuable resource for individuals overwhelmed by the demands of modern life. The current 24-hour day often leaves little time for personal pursuits or simply being. Despite the need for work and family obligations, an extra hour could allow for moments of solitude and self-care. The article argues for a more flexible approach to productivity, allowing individuals the space to pursue their own interests and find balance in their lives.

item.title: For taxpayers, a welcome easing
item.description: The Union Budget 2024-25 proposed a review of the Income Tax Act to simplify its provisions and reduce tax disputes. One significant proposal was to simplify capital gains taxation by introducing a flat tax rate of 12.5% across all asset classes, while eliminating the indexation benefit for property, gold, and unlisted assets. This sparked criticism, leading the government to amend the proposal. Investors now have the option to choose between the lower tax rate of 12.5% without indexation or the existing 20% tax rate with indexation for properties acquired before July 23, 2024. The government's aim is to provide clarity and reduce tax uncertainties for individuals.

item.title: Proposed amendment to Waqf Act polices charity, hinders autonomy
item.description:
The concept of Waqf stems from Islamic religious beliefs, involving the dedication of property for charitable purposes. It is a form of religious charity, not an obligation, and its history is deeply rooted in legal frameworks. The proposed amendments to the Waqf Act, however, raise concerns. They grant extensive government control over Waqf properties, which are considered private and self-acquired by Muslims. Critics argue that this oversteps constitutional guarantees, particularly regarding the management of religious properties and the rights of Muslim citizens.
The amendments also introduce impediments to the creation of new Waqfs and threaten existing ones through the concept of adverse possession. These measures are seen as undermining the autonomy of Waqf institutions and creating vulnerabilities for the Muslim community.

item.title: Vinesh Phogat and the people who abandoned her
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's Olympic journey ended in heartbreak as she was disqualified from the 50kg category due to exceeding the weight limit by a small margin.
This followed an inspiring run where she overcame personal challenges and defeated previously undefeated wrestler Yui Susaki. Despite facing hurdles and being undermined by the system, Phogat displayed courage and resolve, making her a national icon. Her story highlights the need for support and understanding for athletes facing adversity and the important role of women's safety in sports. While the medal eluded her, Phogat's resilience and determination will forever be remembered.

item.title: Behind Sheikh Hasina government’s fall, Bangladesh’s long history of confrontational politics
item.description:
Bangladesh is experiencing political turmoil following student-led protests that escalated into demands for the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. The protests, initially focused on job-quota concerns, reflected a deeper discontent stemming from Bangladesh’s history of cyclical political violence and party rivalry. The situation led to Hasina’s resignation and the establishment of an interim government headed by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus.
The country faces significant challenges, including addressing economic concerns and fostering a democratic ethos. The effectiveness of the interim government depends on its ability to navigate political complexities and engage with diverse stakeholders, including the opposition BNP and Jamaat-e-Islami.
Bangladesh’s relationship with India, marked by economic interdependence and security concerns, is being closely watched as India seeks to promote stability and development in its neighbor.

item.title: Sherni Vinesh: Biggest lesson is that Phogat went to the Olympics a hero — and will come back a bigger one
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's journey at the Paris Olympics, marked by both triumph and disqualification, has resonated deeply with Indian women. Her on-mat success came amidst a struggle for justice against alleged sexual harassment by a powerful wrestling official. Despite immense pressure and distractions, Phogat channeled the anger and support of countless women to reach the final.
Her fight highlights the systemic challenges women face in India, where powerful men often evade accountability and institutions fail to protect them. Phogat's unwavering determination and resilience have made her an icon, symbolizing the strength and power of women who dare to challenge the status quo.

item.title: Vinesh Phogat’s struggle, journey is more valuable than a gold medal
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's disqualification from the Olympics wrestling final for exceeding the weight limit has cast a shadow over her remarkable journey. Despite the heartbreak, Phogat's resilience and refusal to be defined by tragedy shine through. This setback adds to a long list of challenges she has overcome, including a career-threatening knee injury and accusations from the very system meant to support her.
She has fearlessly fought against sexual harassment allegations within the Wrestling Federation of India, highlighting the systemic issues faced by women athletes in India. Phogat's unwavering courage and determination make her an inspiration, a champion who transcends the boundaries of medals and onto a platform of empowerment for women.

item.title: Vinesh Phogat is a winner – for her struggles against sexual harassment and on the mat
item.description:
Vinesh Phogat's journey is one of resilience.
After enduring sexual harassment and a public protest against the Wrestling Federation of India, she has become the first Indian woman wrestler to reach the Olympics final. Despite facing intense criticism and disqualification due to a technicality, her victories on the mat against formidable opponents are a testament to her unwavering spirit. Phogat's victory transcends the sporting arena; her courage in fighting against injustice inspires athletes and advocates for a social change within Indian sports.

item.title: Lesson from coaching centre tragedy: Don’t break the dreams of students
item.description:
The coaching industry in India has grown into a dominant force, pressuring students to achieve success through standardized tests and narrow career paths. This has led to a focus on rote learning and competition, neglecting the joy of learning and the development of well-rounded individuals.
The author argues that this system is detrimental, leading to mental exhaustion, anxiety, and a decline in creativity and critical thinking. They propose three steps to address this issue: redefine the purpose of education to prioritize life skills and compassion, encourage critical thinking and activism against the decline of public education, and restore the meaning of studentship as a lifelong journey of learning and exploration.

item.title: How a wildlife sanctuary in the Great Nicobar Island was made to vanish
item.description:
This article discusses a controversial port project in Great Nicobar Island. The project site, Galathea Bay, was previously designated as a wildlife sanctuary due to its significant ecological value, including nesting grounds for endangered sea turtles and coral reefs.
Despite this, the sanctuary was de-notified, and the project received environmental clearance, raising concerns about environmental damage. The article highlights inconsistencies and questionable decisions made by government agencies, ultimately concluding that the project proceeds despite the area's clear designation as a protected zone. The author argues that environmental considerations were disregarded in favor of development, setting a concerning precedent.

item.title: C Raja Mohan writes: Five years after end of Article 370, what is the Pakistan hand in Kashmir
item.description:
While India's constitutional changes regarding Kashmir have diminished its international salience, the issue remains significant in the bilateral relationship with Pakistan.
The international focus on Kashmir has lessened due to India's economic growth, stronger partnerships with the West and the Islamic world, and Pakistan's internal political divisions. However, Pakistan continues to back cross-border terrorism and opposes the constitutional changes, hindering formal engagement between the two nations. Although civilian leaders in Pakistan have shown interest in dialogue, the military's influence remains strong. India must remain vigilant, addressing internal reconciliation in Kashmir, counterterrorism efforts, and engaging with diverse segments of Pakistani society to ensure lasting peace.

item.title: Boxing with binaries: The Imane Khelif story
item.description: The article discusses the history of sex testing in sport, focusing on the case of Spanish athlete Maria Jose Martinez-Patino who was subjected to traumatic testing due to androgen insensitivity. Sex testing evolved from "nude parades" to chromosome testing before ending in 1999. The debate shifted to testosterone levels, leading to the case of Indian sprinter Dutee Chand, who successfully challenged regulations based on high testosterone. The article argues that the binary insistence on male and female categories in sport is flawed, given the spectrum of biological sex variations. It highlights the case of Martinez-Patino, who later participated in arguments against Chand despite her own experience with problematic testing, demonstrating the complex and often contradictory nature of this issue.

item.title: From Uttarakhand to Wayanad: Balancing realpolitik with green transition
item.description:
India's transition to green energy is characterized by diverse state-led initiatives, reflecting a lack of uniform progress. While the central government has made notable strides in setting targets and promoting collaboration between ministries, challenges persist in areas like transmission infrastructure, energy storage, and securing long-term green finance.
State governments exhibit varying levels of commitment and progress, influenced by factors like policy environment, demographics, and financial resources.
The green energy transition presents a complex policy dilemma, balancing national security concerns regarding dependence on China with the imperative of accelerating the shift to clean energy.
Furthermore, the article highlights the ethical imperative of addressing global warming, urging a shift from nationalistic realpolitik towards a cooperative, global governance framework that prioritizes human well-being and environmental sustainability.

item.title: August 7, 1984, forty years ago: Opposition walkout over ‘draconian laws’
item.description: Clashes erupted in northern Sri Lanka, resulting in the deaths of Tamil separatists and police officers. The Tamil separatists stormed a police station and raided its armory. In India, the opposition walked out of parliament protesting against two new security bills, deeming them "draconian." Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stated that talks with the Akalis were dependent on their willingness to negotiate and refrained from commenting on the concerns raised by the opposition regarding the Madras airport blast.

item.title: Animals on moon, people on Mars: The wrong lessons from Isaac Asimov
item.description: Isaac Asimov's Foundation series depicts a futuristic society facing inevitable collapse, with a scientist establishing a repository of knowledge to preserve humanity. Similarly, modern scientists propose a "lunar biorepository" to safeguard endangered species' DNA against potential extinction from various threats. While this reflects a sci-fi fantasy becoming reality, it risks overshadowing the crucial point that for many, Earth remains their only home. Asimov himself would likely emphasize ethical considerations, urging science to prioritize the well-being of all, not just a privileged few.

item.title: Targeting of Imane Khelif: Sports is a long way away from equality
item.description: The 2024 IOC guidelines promote inclusivity in sports, emphasizing the right of all individuals to participate regardless of gender identity. However, Algerian boxer Imane Khelif and Taiwanese athlete Lin Yu-ting have faced discrimination at the Paris Olympics, highlighting the persisting challenges related to gender identity in sports. Historical gender tests have often been influenced by cultural biases rather than scientific objectivity. Critics of including transgender athletes argue that it undermines the achievements of cisgender women, while athletes like Khelif and Dutee Chand have battled for recognition and acceptance in the face of such prejudice. It is crucial to balance the need for fair competition with respect for the dignity and rights of all athletes.

item.title: A widening war in the Middle East
item.description: Three recent assassinations of top leaders of Iran's proxy forces have escalated tensions in the Middle East, leading to fears of a wider war. While Israel carries out a forceful campaign against Hamas in Gaza, Iran retaliates through proxies, and both countries experience internal divisions and political pressure. Despite the violence and military build-up, there are no clear political goals being met. Neither Israel nor Iran appears closer to achieving their objectives, and the conflict highlights their domestic vulnerabilities and regional isolation.

item.title: From Bangladesh’s students, a message: A fighting chance
item.description:
Bangladesh is experiencing a significant political shift following the end of Sheikh Hasina's rule. This moment presents both opportunities and risks, requiring India to approach the situation with caution and respect for Bangladeshi agency.
While India has legitimate interests in Bangladesh's stability and security, its past support for authoritarianism should be re-evaluated. Simplifying the complex political dynamics by framing events solely through an Islamist lens risks alienating the Bangladeshi people.
Bangladesh faces two main challenges: reconciling its religious and secular identities, and establishing a truly democratic party system. Student movements, with their history of challenging authoritarianism, hold a crucial role in shaping the country's future. India should avoid interfering in Bangladesh's internal processes and instead encourage the country's path towards greater freedom and institutionalization.

item.title: Bengal and Bangladesh are bound together by more than just language
item.description: The article discusses the vandalism of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's statue in Dhaka and its implications for the shared cultural heritage of Bangladesh and India. It highlights the significance of the Language Movement and figures like Rabindranath Tagore and Kazi Nazrul Islam in fostering a united Bengali consciousness. The article emphasizes the importance of rivers and cultural practices like Durga Puja in binding the two nations. It also mentions concerns about the growing influence of neo-nationalist sentiment in Bangladesh and its potential to sever the historical and cultural ties between the two countries.

item.title: In riot-hit Britain, first real test for Keir Starmer’s government
item.description: Recent riots across several British towns, sparked by rumors and misinformation surrounding the stabbing of three girls in Southport, have highlighted the growing influence of far-right ideologies and online hate speech. The violence, which targeted mosques, asylum seeker housing, and other symbols of diversity, has raised serious concerns about the state of civil society and the government's ability to address the root causes of this unrest. While public figures and communities have condemned the violence and expressed solidarity with the victims, the incident has exposed deep-seated anxieties about immigration and the potential for online falsehoods to incite real-world harm. The Labour government faces the urgent challenge of tackling far-right extremism, ensuring swift justice for those responsible, and engaging in honest and constructive dialogue about immigration to counter the divisive rhetoric that fueled these events.

item.title: Big Brother is binge-watching: How proposed law may censor online content
item.description:
The draft Broadcasting Services (Regulation) Bill, 2024 seeks to extend regulations from traditional television to the internet, potentially impacting online speech and creative independence.
The bill defines "digital news broadcasters" broadly, encompassing platforms like YouTube, Twitter, and podcasts discussing current affairs. It mandates registration, adherence to a Programme Code, and pre-certification for non-news content.
Concerns arise from the bill's potential for censorship, particularly concerning political commentators. The broad powers granted to the government, coupled with extra-territorial application, raise questions about its practicality and potential impact on global content creators. The bill also imposes new obligations on social media intermediaries, adding to existing regulatory burdens on free speech. Critics argue that the bill's approach is ill-suited to the decentralized nature of the internet and propose alternative mechanisms like the IT Act 2000 for addressing concerns about harmful content. The authors advocate for thorough deliberation and stakeholder engagement before the bill is enacted, emphasizing its significant implications for the future of online expression in India.

item.title: With Bangladesh in turmoil, why India should exercise caution
item.description:
The political landscape in Bangladesh has shifted dramatically with the resignation of Sheikh Hasina and the rise of army control. Protests triggered by economic hardship and government corruption have led to this change.
India should acknowledge the Bangladeshi people's right to self-determination and support their expression of will. While acknowledging the positive developments in India-Bangladesh relations under Hasina's rule, it's important to allow the situation to stabilize and avoid taking sides. India should prioritize economic engagement with a future government while also maintaining a cautious and discreet approach.
Pakistan and China might try to exploit the situation to challenge India's influence, but Delhi should focus on strengthening its ties with the Bangladeshi people based on shared interests and cultural affinities.

item.title: On the stock market slump: Fall and correct
item.description: The US Federal Reserve's recent comments, hinting at a potential interest rate cut, had initially buoyed markets. However, weaker-than-expected US jobs data raised concerns about the economy, triggering a global sell-off. The Indian market was heavily impacted, with the Sensex plunging over 2 percent. The fall was exacerbated by worries about valuations in certain segments of the Indian stock market. Global factors, including the Bank of Japan's interest rate hike and Middle East tensions, also contributed to the market turmoil. The upcoming RBI monetary policy meeting and domestic economic data releases are expected to influence the market's future movement.

item.title: UK riots: A deliberate challenge to new Labour government
item.description: Violence erupted in numerous UK cities following the stabbing of three young girls by a 17-year-old man. Though the arrested individual was not a Muslim, far-right groups quickly spread false information, fueling anti-Muslim sentiment and leading to attacks on mosques and Muslim-owned businesses. This unrest reflects a pattern of growing violence against women and a rise in Islamophobia in the UK, fueled by political rhetoric and economic anxieties. Prime Minister Keir Starmer and his government have condemned the violence and vowed to hold the perpetrators accountable, while civil society organizations and communities are working to counter the spread of hate and support victims.

item.title: Yamini Krishnamurthy: Born to dance
item.description:
Yamini Krishnamurthy, a celebrated classical dancer who mastered Bharatnatyam, Kuchupudi, and Odissi, passed away on August 3. Born into a scholarly family, her passion for dance was ignited by the artistry of temple sculptures.
She honed her skills at Kalakshetra under Rukmini Devi Arundale, but it was under the guidance of nattuvanars like Elappa Pillai and Kitappa Pillai that she found the expression and style that defined her artistry. Krishnamurthy's captivating performances, known for their precision, intricate footwork, and glamour, captivated audiences across India and the world. She received numerous accolades, including the Padma Shri in 1968, and held the esteemed title of Asthana Narthaki at the Tirupati Tirumala temple. Krishnamurthy's legacy as a trailblazer in classical dance endures.

item.title: August 6, 1984, Forty Years Ago: Madras blast
item.description: India has rejected Sri Lanka's proposal for a joint inquiry into the bomb blast at Madras airport, stating that the question doesn't arise. The statement came amidst unclear claims regarding responsibility for the attack. Indian authorities are preparing to prosecute several Akali leaders under the National Security Act for charges related to waging war against the country and sedition connected to the fighting at the Golden Temple complex. The investigation in this case is ongoing. Separately, India finalized a deal with the Soviet Union to purchase MiG-29 fighter jets, perceived as having capabilities comparable to F-16 Falcons and F-18 Hornet aircraft.

item.title: Express View: The fall of Sheikh Hasina
item.description: Sheikh Hasina's recent resignation and fleeing from Bangladesh follows a period of growing unrest and challenges to her authority. Despite her party's electoral victory, the election was marred by allegations of rigging and a boycott by opposition parties. Protests against job quotas escalated into nationwide demonstrations, met with a harsh response from the government that resulted in significant casualties. The recent turmoil highlights the limitations of Hasina's development narrative and her increasingly authoritarian methods. Her unyielding stance on historical narratives and the suppression of dissent alienated segments of the populace, potentially paving the way for the resurgence of Islamist and pro-Pakistan sentiments. Hasina's downfall presents a challenge for India, which must now navigate the complexities of maintaining its relationship with Bangladesh while safeguarding its interests in the face of rising internal instability.

item.title: Why Sheikh Hasina had to flee Bangladesh — and the lesson from her ouster
item.description:
Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's longtime Prime Minister, resigned after 15 years in power. Her rule, characterized by notable economic progress, was marred by alleged authoritarianism, suppression of dissent, and widespread corruption. Protests, initially sparked by student demands for quota reforms, escalated into a broader movement against her government's policies.
The public's anger was fueled by the government's response to the protests, which included the deployment of force and the labelling of demonstrators as traitors. Hasina's departure signifies a turning point in Bangladesh's political landscape, highlighting the delicate balance between economic development and democratic values.

item.title: How to deal with terrorism in Jammu
item.description:
Recent events in Jammu have demonstrated a resurgence of Pakistan-sponsored terrorism, with militants exploiting voids created by a shift in focus to other conflicts.
This situation echoes past patterns of infiltration and tactical strategies employed by terrorists over the years. To address this, a unified command, leveraging intelligence and engaging the local population, is crucial. Synergy between the Army and CAPFs is essential, alongside re-equipping and training Village Defence Guards.
The experience of previous counter-terrorism operations, including the successful strategy of clearing jungle areas and denying terrorists refuge, should be revisited. Ultimately, sustained operations and effective logistics management are key to outmaneuvering and neutralizing the threat.

item.title: Behind the UK race riots: Anti-immigrant sentiment, Islamophobia and economic distress
item.description: The UK is experiencing riots following a knife attack in Southport that killed three children. The unrest, concentrated in England, is fueled by discontent towards immigrants, perceived to be competing for resources like housing and jobs. Economic stagnation since 2008 has exacerbated these feelings. Previous riots in the 1970s, spurred by socio-economic disparities and racial tensions, resulted in police reforms. The UK's exit from Europe, driven by anxieties over immigration, further heightened these concerns. Islamophobia, amplified by the tragic incident's false associations to Muslims, fueled the recent unrest. While authorities promise swift action against rioters, the underlying economic issues require urgent addressing to prevent further social unrest.

item.title: The irrational bull run: When stock market is driven by FOMO
item.description:
The Indian stock market significantly declined, triggered by growing concerns about the US economy. While domestic flows have driven the market lately, high valuations in India, defying logic, raise concerns about a deeper correction.
Though bulls have attempted to justify the continuous upward movement, the current cycle seems driven by fear of missing out and greed rather than fundamentals. A price-to-earnings ratio similar to levels seen before the 2007 bull market peak is a warning sign. Even companies with mediocre growth and challenging operating environments are experiencing soaring valuations. Market segments like small and midcaps and public sector companies exhibit extreme exuberance.
Some CEO comments highlight this disconnect, with companies stating concerns about GDP correlation and challenging demand conditions while their stocks trade at inflated PE ratios. The question is whether the market will eventually adopt a more realistic view of valuations and growth prospects or if the bull run will continue.

item.title: Furore over Imane Khelif’s gender is fueled by Western prejudice
item.description: Women athletes from less prominent nations are challenging the Western dominance of the Olympics. They are overcoming political, religious, and social hurdles, balancing their athletic aspirations with motherhood and family obligations. Despite lacking the resources and support systems of their Western counterparts, they are embodying the true Olympic spirit. The success of athletes like Algerian boxer Imane Khelif and Egyptian fencer Nada Hafez has sparked controversy and accusations of unfair advantage. These women, many wearing hijabs, are shattering stereotypes and proving that talent and determination can triumph over societal barriers.

item.title: August 5, 1984, Forty Years Ago: PM Indira Gandhi accused foreign powers of working against India’s interest
item.description:
Indira Gandhi accused foreign powers of interfering in India's internal affairs by inciting riots and promoting regionalism. She urged Congress supporters to defeat opposition parties in the upcoming Lok Sabha elections to safeguard national interests.
In Karnataka, Chief Minister Rama Krishna Hegde accused Kranti Ranga leader S Bangarappa of attempting to destabilize his government by enticing Janata Party members with ministerial positions.
Indian athlete Shiny Abraham made history by becoming the first Indian woman to qualify for the 800 meters semi-final at the Los Angeles Olympics. The Army was deployed in Uttar Pradesh to assist in flood relief efforts following breaches in embankments, impacting several districts.

item.title: August 5, 2024: Five years on, did ending special status for Jammu & Kashmir achieve its ends?
item.description:
Five years after the abrogation of Article 370, Jammu and Kashmir has seen improvements in economic development, governance, and tourism. While security remains a concern with increasing infiltration in the Jammu sector and Pakistan's continued involvement in sponsoring terrorism, the region has experienced a record voter turnout in the recent elections. Despite these advancements, restoring statehood remains a crucial step.
A calibrated approach with clear timelines and active people's involvement in governance is essential. The government must address the concerns of the people, as their participation is key to building trust and alleviating alienation.

item.title: AIIMS software can extend specialist care for diabetics in rural areas
item.description:
The Covid-19 pandemic highlighted the potential of telemedicine in managing chronic diseases like diabetes. Recognizing this, a software developed by AIIMS, Delhi, aims to extend specialized diabetes consultation to primary healthcare centers in rural India. The software assists local healthcare professionals by processing patient data on risk factors and suggesting treatment, thus addressing the challenge of undiagnosed diabetes and limited specialist access in rural areas.
However, this technology's effectiveness relies on the expertise of healthcare providers who adapt the software's advice to individual patient needs. Data confidentiality and seamless integration with the National Health Programme for Non-Communicable Diseases are crucial for the software's wider impact.

item.title: Budget 2024-25 allows youth to lead path of growth in India
item.description:
The 2024-25 budget focuses on merging skill and scale to empower India's young workforce. Acknowledging the demographic dividend, the budget aims to improve employability by incentivizing internships and skilling programs. A key initiative offers Rs. 5,000 monthly stipends to one crore graduates interning with top companies, training expenses covered by corporate social responsibility funds.
The budget also prioritizes agriculture, proposing measures to support FPOs, boost climate-resistant crops, and promote natural farming. To stimulate employment, new schemes are introduced to encourage hiring through direct benefits to first-time employees and employers.
Significant allocations are made for affordable housing programs and healthcare, while women's empowerment initiatives receive increased funding. The budget aims to benefit the middle class through income tax reforms and the growth of eastern states is supported by a new Purvodaya scheme.

item.title: Abrogating Article 370 was a necessary, but not sufficient condition for ending terrorism
item.description: The article analyzes the factors contributing to terrorism in Jammu and Kashmir. It highlights Pakistan's role in promoting radical Islam and using the conflict for political gain, as well as the influence of Cold War geopolitics and strained federalism. The article argues that the abrogation of Article 370 has contributed to a decline in violence, but emphasizes the need for ongoing efforts to address the root causes of terrorism, including strengthening the J&K Police, enhancing political inclusivity, and isolating Pakistan geopolitically.

item.title: Five years since abrogation of Article 370: How Kashmir can help build a national counter-narrative
item.description:
The Jammu and Kashmir Budget 2024-25 reveals a concerning economic picture five years after the abrogation of Article 370. Despite increased borrowing, public investment has declined sharply. Tax incidence and efficiency have also decreased, while the unemployment rate remains high. The abrogation, while ending the previous political discourse on Kashmir, has failed to deliver on promises of peace and prosperity. Social media celebration of its revocation masks the underlying anxiety and disillusionment in Kashmir. Valley-centric political parties find themselves struggling to articulate a meaningful alternative, as the reality of a redefined role for the government sets in.
While restoring statehood enjoys national support, it is insufficient to address the complex socio-economic challenges facing Kashmir. The political leadership needs to engage in a transformative process, re-evaluating their ideology and re-positioning themselves to represent the plural, progressive aspirations of the people. This is the time for Kashmir to play a crucial role in shaping a more inclusive national narrative.

item.title: Vandita Mishra writes: The court and social justice
item.description:
The Supreme Court recently permitted the sub-classification of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes for reservation purposes. This decision allows states to differentiate within these categories to fine-tune affirmative action policies. The court emphasized the importance of empirical evidence and a clear rationale for sub-classification, subject to judicial review.
While the ruling aims to address disparities within SC/ST communities, concerns have been raised about potential constitutional violations, political manipulation, and increased competition among marginalized groups. To ensure fair implementation, a comprehensive caste census is crucial.
The verdict highlights the complex interplay of social justice, politics, and legal interpretations in India.

item.title: Would Kamala Harris have succeeded in India? It’s unlikely
item.description:
This article explores the contrasting journeys of Kamala Harris and Usha Vance, two prominent Indian women in the US political landscape. Both exemplify the immigrant experience, leveraging their traditional Indian values and educational achievements to attain success. The author contrasts their rise in a society that encourages individuality and opportunity with the perceived limitations and societal pressures faced by similarly qualified Indians in their home country.
The article argues that cultural norms and systemic issues in India stifle innovation and ambition, leading to a culture of mediocrity. It laments that while women like Harris and Vance thrive in a welcoming environment that values diversity, Indian society often discourages risk-taking and personal fulfillment. Ultimately, the author suggests that India needs to foster a more inclusive and empowering environment to encourage its citizens to reach their full potential.

item.title: What is a ‘privileged Dalit’? Creamy Layer definition cannot just be economic
item.description:
A recent Supreme Court judgement on sub-classification within SC and ST groups for reservation raises questions about its necessity and implementation.
The author shares a personal experience of caste-based discrimination despite financial security, highlighting the persistence of social inequalities. While acknowledging the need to revisit reservations in light of changing social dynamics, the author questions how to objectively define who is most marginalised and fears that the reform could be exploited for political gain. The author emphasizes that economic progress alone does not eradicate the social disadvantages faced by Dalits, and a comprehensive caste survey is necessary to effectively address this issue. Ultimately, the author argues that reservation, envisioned as a tool for achieving social equity and dismantling caste-based discrimination, must be preserved to ensure the continued upliftment of marginalized communities.

item.title: International Conference of Agricultural Economists: A chance to cement India-Africa partnership in food security
item.description:
The 32nd International Conference of Agricultural Economists (ICAE) is being held in Delhi, India, marking the country's second time hosting this global event. ICAE, with roots tracing back to Rabindranath Tagore and Lord L K Elmhirst's vision in 1921, focuses on global food and nutritional security.
A unique study presented at ICAE compares the agricultural practices and outcomes of 20 Indian states with 15 African countries, highlighting key areas for improvement. Both regions face challenges such as underfunding of agricultural research and development, and low agricultural spending relative to social protection.
The study recommends prioritizing investments in agricultural R&D and extension, reforming subsidies, and allocating resources to infrastructure development to boost agricultural growth and enhance child nutrition.
The conference emphasizes the need for South-South collaboration, particularly between India and Africa, to address pressing food and nutritional security challenges, learning from each other's experiences and working together to build resilient food systems.
